Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Jun 19, 11:09am, Tim Beauchamp wrote:
> Subject: Re: possibly important: bad tabs?
> Dissimination of Information:
>
> > Strychnine isn't strong enough to have any effect in the small doses
> > you'd need to try and fit it on a tab/in a microdot.  I usd to think so
> > too, but strychnine in acid is an urban legend ....
>
> Well for anybody who cares, here's what I've picked up over the years:
> 1.  the "urban legend" I'm sure everybody has heard, that strychnine
> (or speed) was added to acid to give you that body-buzz and enhance the
> effect.  Never having met anybody that made acid, I believed it.

Too bad. Both speed and strychnine are only active in milligram quantities
(LSD in the microgram range) and therefore (as the first post said) can
not be impregnated in large enough amounts in tab/blotter/microdot to
give _any_effect.

> 2.  Flipside magazine a couple of years ago ran a series of articles,
> "Just Say Know", one of which was dedicated to acid (I can give exact
> references to anybody that wants) where the author gave the low-down on
> the dozen or so variations on the lsd molecule each of which had
> slightly different effects ranging from nothing at all to mind/body
> blowing experences (lsd-25 being the best)  As he pointed out, most
> people cooking probably don't know about these let alone how to test
> for them and how to guarentee a particular variant.  Some of those
> variants gave the body-buzz, hot-cold flashes, stomache cramps, etc...
> normally associated with strychnine--i.e., there is no strychnine in acid

Correct. Actually I believed this to be the right explanation at first
and still think it could play a role (I am a chemist by profession btw).
However, I asked a Dutch chemist friend of mine who is a walking
encyclopedia (sp?) on psychedelics and their pharmacology and he said
it is more likely to be due to an overload of not only your central
nervous system ("the trip") but also the nerves connected to your
stomach, kind of like when your nervous or deeply in love (butterflies..)
and it gets to your stomach or bowels ;-) I've seen situations were
two people shared the same blotter acid and only one of them had
stomach trouble, apparently it depends more on the person than the
acid, in agreement with the last explanation.

> 3. Last fall, I met a person who claimed to have cooked acid with
> `professionals' and he said they `painted' the sheets of paper used for
> blotter with strychnine as a preservative.

Very unlikely, strychnine is mostly used to kill rodents (again in milligrams
that do not fit on a tab). It would make more sense to add an anti-oxidant
since LSD is sensitive to light and air (store in your fridge!). Unless
these people had a serious problem with psychedelic rats eating their
blotters by the dozen this seems not very "profesional".

> There's my collected knowledge on the subject, you make the call.

OK, for the very last time, their is no strychnine in acid, and even if
there would be, the dose would be too small to have any effect.
(check out alt.drugs where this theme comes back every so many weeks
and people are getting _really_ bored with repeating the same thing
over and over again.)

> I am not promoting the use of LSD as that would be inappropriate on
> this list and inappropriate to several hundred people I don't know-
> -it's not for everybody.  As the scientist who discovered LSD says,
> "LSD is for the prepared mind"

Or "his trouble child", I completely agree.

>
> Tim -- lurking no more
>
> P.S. Feel free to correct or add to anything I stated above (perhaps by
>      direct reply to me if it's not appropriate for the list)

I think it's appropriate, but perhaps this could be the final word...

The Frying Dutchman



--

Subject: Summer Solstice...
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



My dog and I caught a beautiful Pacific sunset up on Bolinas Ridge last night.  
Man, the whole time I could hear the faint beat of bongos from the next ridge 
over.  Even better, about an hour after sunset the stars were out and I started to 
feel these soft warm winds sweeping up from the valley below.  I can't describe 
how relaxing it was to feel those warm winds at night.

Anyhow, point being the summer solstice is this Friday.  Does anybody know of any 
outdoor events scheduled?  Please shoot me some mail if you do. Otherwise I'll 
have to get all Mayan up on Mt. Tam 'cause the weather is just too inviting.

Your Pal Always,
-SUNNY (Solle Clothing Co.) 

P.S. Hey, does anybody out there remember "Felix The Cat" outside of Santa Rosa or 
wherever it was, Summer '92 I think?  Boy, something like that would hit the spot 
right now.

Raver culture

200$ Answer: A large party, in excess of 5000 people in attendance.

400$ Answer: This is a raver's favorite vowel.

600$ Answer: Past tense of a car losing control or how a raver feels after
many hours/days of dancing.

800$ Answer: An acronym for a raver mode of thought regarding well being
amongst ravers and non-ravers alike.

1000$ Answer: A date in raver-lore to when the whole shebang and the ultimate
end of everything is coming, thus giving reasons for promoters to throw even
funer, more vibe-filled and faster, events.



"dance with me..."


-Adam

What is e?
>600$ Answer: Past tense of a car losing control or how a raver feels after
>many hours/days of dancing.
What is crashed?
>800$ Answer: An acronym for a raver mode of thought regarding well being
>amongst ravers and non-ravers alike.
What is PLUR?
>1000$ Answer: A date in raver-lore to when the whole shebang and the ultimate
>end of everything is coming, thus giving reasons for promoters to throw even
>funer, more vibe-filled and faster, events.
(uh...uh...*BZZZT*)
>
>
>"dance with me..."

> Sacramento is not a very good place to have a rave.    Almost all parties get
> shut down sooner or later.....

Yeah.. just about the only places left are Cal Expo (Smarties and Funky 
Tekno Tribe), under the Yolo Causeway on 80 when it's not flooded, and 
way out in BFE in a warehouse.  Anything in DOWNTOWN Sac will get 
busted.... I don't know why nobody's trying to do parties in warehouses 
this summer... last summer there were a ton of good parties that didn't 
even come close to get busted, all in warehouses... Liquid Groove, Common 
Ground, Tribal Funk, X-Files, and Ooga Booga all went off in warehouse or 
underground locations last year.

I think it's just the fact that nobody here wants to try because someone 
throws a party in the city the same night and nobody wants to drive all 
the way out here :)

> Sacramento is not a very good place to have a rave.    Almost all parties get
> shut down sooner or later.....

	But just past Sac the ground bulges up into the air and forms 
tall pointy things and large bowls and ridges and... There are many dirt 
roads which wonder trough these landscapes some of which people have 
followed. If more people followed these roads and brought some of the 
speaker cabinet things and some amps, some signal conditioning stuff, a 
genny, turntables, a mixer, and loads of cables to make spagetti with, we 
could have a party... Now if people would just drive up those dirt roads...

dave

ELEVATION 96 Sometime in August

Some might recall Elevation last fall equinox.  Fillip and I threw that party
on my friends space about 1.5 hrs into the mountains, midlle of no where, 10
miless of dirt road.  We had nearly well over 100 folks from all over out
there, one of the nicest outdoor parties I've been to. Gavin & many others
called best ever.  Well keep yer ears peeled for the next one.  That space is
still available but I'd like to find something closer.  We've also got a
couple of bands/artists that will be playing daytime for this one.

For catching all the jepoardy questions....  

> Raver culture
> 
> 200$ Answer: A large party, in excess of 5000 people in attendance.
massive
> 
> 400$ Answer: This is a raver's favorite vowel.
e
> 
> 600$ Answer: Past tense of a car losing control or how a raver feels after
> many hours/days of dancing.
spun
> 
> 800$ Answer: An acronym for a raver mode of thought regarding well being
> amongst ravers and non-ravers alike.
plur
> 
> 1000$ Answer: A date in raver-lore to when the whole shebang and the
ultimate
> end of everything is coming, thus giving reasons for promoters to throw
even
> funer, more vibe-filled and faster, events.
2012


And the grand prize is... 

2Lbs of Blowpops!!!  Oh, and of course the 3000$, payable in Monopoly 
money... =)

howdy all 
a couple of weeks ago I went to amsterdam and isreal via germany, (some 
pics at  http://shgc-www.stanford.edu/~piercy/fun.html) Well amsterdam 
was pretty crazy it's nice to be in a place were you dont have to hide 
like a criminal while smoking potIn Frankfurt I watched some MTV style 
show that played Jungle videos and then had a DJ mix live in front of the 
camera(very strange) in Isreal EVERY where was trance.  In amsterdam it 
was all about jungle I picked up some flyers there-seems like alchohol is 
a big part of the club seen,go figure-I mean its Amsterdam why drink, you 
can buy mushrooms ant your local head shop (remember these are the 
imperesions of a visitor-maybee i got the wrong flyers)  Isreal was 
definatly diferent I felt kinda like an outsider(not being jewish or arab) 

 I had a really facinating conversation with a young Isreali 
guy-so funny i wrote it down maybee it'll go on my page.  It was amazing 
being in a place with so much history and so much tension-it took me an 
hour to get out of the airport due to the exit interview that every one 
must go thru, becouse I fly on an Airline discount i cant reserve a seat 
the plane was full so i had to sit in a little fold-out seat behind the 
captain that was pretty starnge-especially landing.  Basically electronic 
music is totally accepted as 'normal' there(last time i went it still 
seemed obscure) and that was bizare to me-in this place it still gets put 
down quite alot-I geuss I prefer it that way, but i'm strange that 
way-not to many Lucky Srtike sponsered massives here... yet
SEe ya
MArk

> I think it's just the fact that nobody here wants to try because someone 
> throws a party in the city the same night and nobody wants to drive all 
> the way out here :)

To me, San Francisco just has a different feel to her raves.  I know most 
of the promoters in Sac and I appreciate what all of them are doing, and 
occasionally I will attend a club that they are doing.  But like John 
Deatherage pointed out, Sac gets BUSTED!  (with a few exceptions) And so 
I would just rather not go.  

Hm...plus I just KNOW more people in SF.  I go to a Sac party, and i know 
the people throwing the event - and, hell, they're busy!  I'm putting 
more energy into the SF vibe anyways, because it will be my HOME by the 
end of this year (if all goes as planned...)

love,
Amy

On Jun 20,  9:06am, Mark Piercy wrote:
> Subject: my euro-trip and such

Ah you visited the truly home of the free! ;-)

> Well amsterdam
> was pretty crazy it's nice to be in a place were you dont have to hide
> like a criminal while smoking pot.

Isn't it wonderful? With the European Community coming things might get
more restricted since our neighbouring countries complain that every
body is importing Dutch pot from Holland. Did you try the Dutch-grown
superskunk? Highest THC content in the world I believe. Guaranteed to
knock you off your socks...

> In amsterdam it  was all about jungle I picked up some flyers

Mostly among the black kids, we have everything from 200 bpm gabber to
easy tunes (latest trend). Check out the Mazzo next time (I heard they
are back at their old (great) location after a fire. Great techno under-
ground club.

> there-seems like alchohol is a big part of the club seen,go figure-

And vice versa I'm still amazed by the attitude here concerning alcohol.
In my impression one almost forces people to use dope (at the Tibetan Freedom
concert it was hard to see the bands through the potsmoke clouds). At home
those who don't like to get high/tweek just have a beer and are still
cool. I feel it's better to inform/educate people and learn them some
responsibility than treating them like little kids. Here you have a
beautiful country with great weather and you can not even drink a cold
beer on the beach/at a street terrace or after 2 o'clock at night. Weird.

> I mean its Amsterdam why drink, you can buy mushrooms at your local head shop

And via the internet! (USD accepted, see http://www.xs4all.nl/~psee/)
Again, in Holland we leave it up to the people what they want to do,
Wanna smoke weed? Fine. Wanna have a beer? Fine too. We don't force
anybody to do anything and still the nightlife/raves/clubs are as
relaxed as over here. Perhaps it's not the alcohol but the attitude?
Here there seem to be laws againts anything that is even remotely fun,
no wonder people take it to extremes when they get the chance
(I'm still amazed for instance by the ease and quantity with which
acid is used in this country, now that's a drug which should be used
with a bit more respect and caution).

> (remember these are the imperesions of a visitor-maybee i got the wrong
> flyers)

No, alcohol is present as almost any rave, no ID's are checked, if you're
18 you're considered adult and basically anything goes. Police policy
is not to arrest the users but to get the large-scale traders....
Leave it to the people and inform them rather then arrest them, let
them learn from their own mistakes (=better them having somebody
telling you what's best)

I liked your webpage (feeling homesick seeing the canal...).
Sorry if I sounded a bit harsh (too much coffee this morning? Hehe,
another typical American habbit), just trying to explain some cultural
differences here,

Cheers,

The Frying Dutchman




--

Here are the directions for In-Organic. A $5 donations rave put on by 
your friendly SoCal people this Friday before Organic. Hope to see you 
some there.

Aleph One / aleph1@dfw.net
http://underground.org/
KeyID 1024/948FD6B5 
Fingerprint EE C9 E8 AA CB AF 09 61  8C 39 EA 47 A8 6A B8 01 

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 19 Jun 1996 17:01:52 -0700 (PDT)
From: Andy Kumeda <kumeda@intelenet.net>
To: socal-raves@ucsd.edu
Cc: formulapr@aol.com, hilkey@fa.disney.com, jking@ssla.sgi.com
Subject: In-Organic Directions [corrected]

Ok, here it is!

The map point will open promptly at 8pm and will close around 1am, so
PLEASE arrive as early as possible.

The detailed directions will begin at the 10/215 intersection, so it
will assume that you will be able to find your way there.  I think most,
if not all of you have been to the Orange Show at one time or another.
If you don't know where it is, consult your local California roadmap,
and if you still need further assistance, leave a message on the
voice-mail line and I'll get back to you.

The number in the parentheses is the milage, so when you get to the
10/30, zero out your trip meter.

========================================================================

>From the 10/215 intersection, take the 215 north for 5.9 miles to the 
30 east.

You should now be at the intersection of the 215 and the 30 freeway, so
zero out your trip meter.
(0.0)

Continue on the 30 for 5.3 miles until you see the 330.  The sign should
read Mountain Resorts.
(5.3)

You will see a sign that says welcome to the San Bernardino Mountains on
your right at the base of the mountain.
(7.3)

On your left, you will see a Forest Service station.
(10.5)

Continue on this road...

After a little while, you will come to a fork near Running Springs.
Continue under the bridge towards Big Bear.
(21.0)

On your left, you'll see a Union station.  If you don't have gas at this
point, get it there because you won't find one until you get into town.
(21.4)

A few miles down the road, you'll get to Green Valley where KC and a
bunch of others will be camped out.  DO NOT turn!
(23.9)

Keep on driving....

On your right will be Snow Valley -- site of Organic!
(26.9)

About a mile later, you will reach a spot where you can almost see the
lake.  This is the beginning of the Arctic Circle.
(28.4)

Continue on this winding road til you get to a fork.  This is the dam at
the edge of the lake.  Turn right.
(33.8)

After driving on the south side of the lake (Big Bear lake will be to
your left), you'll see a Texaco gas station on your right, and a sign
welcoming you to Big Bear straight ahead.  Turn left onto Paine Rd.
(37.8)

Paine turns into Big Bear Blvd (Hwy 18), which is the one and only main
boulevard that goes through the town.  About a mile and a half down,
you'll see a Shell gas station on your right.  This is Summit Blvd, and
to your right is Snow Summit.  Keep on going...
(39.6)

After another mile, you'll see an AM/PM on your right.  Continue on...
(40.8)

You will soon see the Big Bear Convention Center on your left.  This is
Division.  Keep on going... you're almost there.
(41.8)

Finally, on your left, you'll see a Chevron station.  Turn left onto
Greenway -- the only signal intersection in Bear City.
(43.1) 

The map point will be at the Big Bear City Park on your right.  Turn in
and you'll see someone there.  Please don't loiter around there -- leave
for the site as soon you recieve your map. 


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Jun 20 12:06:22 1996

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 19 Jun 1996 15:55:47 -0700 (PDT)
From: Andy Kumeda <kumeda@intelenet.net>
To: socal-raves@ucsd.edu
Subject: In-Organic (6/21/96)

Here are a few things to remember or keep in mind -- please respect our
wishes so that we can continue to bring you more high-quality events in 
the future.  (Directions to the map point will follow shortly in a
separate e-mail.)  

Also, please forward this message, along with the directions to those
that are not on socal-raves -- thanks. 

Things to bring:
o  layered clothing -- it gets chilly at night (low 40's), and very 
   warm (80's) during the day
o  blankets, tents, and sleeping bags for warmth and to rest up for 
   Organic
o  food and drinks (free water will be provided if necessary)
o  fire extinguisher(s) if you own one (in case of emergency)
o  candy, toys, and other goodies to share with everyone

Things NOT to bring OR do:
o  hazardous/flammable material of any kind -- ie no fireworks,
   campfires, flame-throwers, or smoking outside of designated areas
o  nitrous tanks and/or balloons -- ABSOLUTELY NO EXCEPTIONS

General tips:
o  PLEASE DO NOT attempt to drive if not completely sober and awake
o  PLEASE DO NOT disturb wildlife or its natural surroundings -- respect 
   Mother Nature
o  PLEASE DO NOT wander onto the main road from the site (to avoid 
   attracting any unnecessary attention)
o  PLEASE throw trash away in one of the several trashcans situated near
   the dance area
o  PLEASE keep the music down in your cars as you are travelling through
   town and in populated areas -- the law enforcement in Big Bear do not
   take too kindly to loud, repetitive digital music

Things TODO:
o  ooze excess PLUR and share with those that are a little lacking
o  hug at least one person you don't know, smile, or just say hello
o  if you see trash, please pick it up and deposit at the nearest trashcan 
o  MOST OF ALL HAVE LOTS OF FUN!!! 

Ok, and the final details...

BBQ will begin around 6pm, so bring your fave item to throw on the
barbie.

The roads leading to the site are a little bumpy, but should be
accessible by any vehicle.  If you arrive after sunset, drive slow, and
keep your eye out for rocks and ditches.  We will be trying to clear out
all major obstacles before you all arrive to make the drive as smooth as
possible.

There will be free goodies to the first 200 people, so again, arrive
early.

Finally, the cost for this event is ONLY $5.

Hope to see you all there!!!

July 21st 1996!  Come celebrate the summer solstice with us and dance
under the stars with ....    

                   *  *   *  **  *   *   * *   * *    *  
                *                                   * *
     ! ! ! ! !           I N  - - -  O R G A N I C       ! ! ! ! ! !
                  * *                                   * 
                 *  * *    * **  *  * * *** *    *      *



OK everyone,

I think this'll be the last update for IN-ORGANIC before I post the
directions to the map point here this Thursday.  

Well, first of all, I'd like to ask all the volunteers that responded to
me that wished to help out with the party to get back to me ASAP so that
I may arrange cabin space for you.  Just a reminder, we are looking for
people to volunteer some time to help with doing 'party stuff' in 
exchange for cabin space.  So if you're interested, please get back to 
me ASAP!  Thanks.

Alrighty...
The DJ lineup has been confirmed (in order of appearance):
	Superstar DJ Trouble (need I say more?)
	KC (Dune)
	Brad (Mother Earth)
	Daniel (Moontribe)
Note that there may be some last minute additions/changes.

Sound will be provided by Ohm Soundlabs, who will bring out the same
system that was present at the last Moontribe, so the forest will be
rocking!

Medical support will be provided by Medi-Rave!

We will have BBQ grills at the location starting at around 5pm, so come
out early and grub with us.  Please bring your favorite grillable items,
since we won't be able to provide food for everyone.  If anyone is
interested in joining our little BBQ gathering, please RSVP as soon as
possible by sending me an e-mail.

Also, remember that this party is not limited to the socal list people, 
so spread the word to those that aren't on the list.  As long as they
bring good vibes, all are welcome! 

We also ask that if anyone has a fire extinguisher, that they would
bring it and leave it in their cars -- just in case.  We will have
several, but it'll be nice to have a few more laying around.  Speaking
of fires, remember folks that there is to be NO FIRES of any kind!  Do
NOT SMOKE in the mountains!  We will be designating a smoking area, so
please do not light up anywhere outside of there -- PLEASE!

Finally, we will NOT be allowing ANY nitrous tanks anywhere near the
area.  If you are planning on bringing one -- DON'T!  

If you can't check your e-mail Thursday for directions to the map point,
just call the following number:

                   7  1  4 - 2  2  4  9  7  7  9

See you all there!

Nope, you were wrong about Duran Duran's original name.

Arcadia was the band that Simon, Nick and Roger formed after D2 broke up 
for a brief time.  Arcadia's  most famous singles included "Re-election 
Day" and "Goodbye is Forever".

Duran Duran's original name was RAF.  Someone said it was Barbarella, but 
that was the name of the movie in which they got their name, Duran Duran.

I don't know if anyone really even cares, but I worshiped this band long 
ago, and this is the only question on the list that nobody can get.  
Trust me, it is right! :)

My apologies for taking up bandwidth on sfraves, beign that this is is 
off topic.

so an obrave: we should have a rave with an 80's dress up theme! :):)

love,
Amy

That's right, kiddies: Stella Luna will be providing atmospheric,
vibe-inspiring, energy-invoking music (might call it ambient noise) to
celebrate the Summer Solstice!  It happens this Friday night at midnight,
at the Towne Theatre in downtown San Jose.  It's free, and there will be
wonderful people there, some of whom you may know; it's always a pleasant
surprise to see people show up "out of the blue" for these shows.  If you
can, I encourage you to attend!  Welcome the summer of '96 :)

Peace,

- E

Subject: Gateway Light / Solstice Party in East Bay!(bsp)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Hello all you wonderful summer fun lovers!  This Friday is Gateway's 1 year
anniversary Light Summer Solstice Celebration.  The line-up is in order
starting at 1pm. ending at 10p.m. Conciousness Lab (ambient meditation) then,
Monty, Galen, Andre Lucero, Jon Williams, John Carel, and a short closing
ambient meditation.  We are encouraging everyone to bring some type of
creative exchange like games, food, drums, didjeridoos, smiles, friends,
anything to share and celebrate!  There will be volleyball, croquette,  kiddy
pools w/ water, and a special art area.  The park is in Oakland near the
airport and is beautiful.  Directions are:  Take 580 tward the Oakland
Airport, Exit Hagenburger Rd., make the 1st right onto Edgewater, go up 1/4
mile and turn left onto Pardee.  Pull into the dirt parking lot directly on
your right.  The path into the park is paved and marked. Come and play in the
sun on the day with the most light! 
                                                    Feel it - Love!
                                                 -Gateway Systems

Light kicks off the weekend and the summer with an outdoor tomorrow...from
there head off to the Chemical Bros show, or any of the other parties, they
all look pretty hot.  On Monday, Underworld and Orbital hit town after
playing in SoCal over the weekend.

Word has it that the Top has also had to turn it down for a while - check 
back later for events to start up again.

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning 3am-6am - "Aural Fixation"
       experimental sounds of ambient and trip hop with a splash of hi
       nrg, from trance to jungle. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Subject: I had a dream!  Radio Free Utopia
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I had just hopped in my 1968 Datsun Roadster Convertible, with the most
beautiful woman on earth next to me, AKA Ahnon.  I reached for the tuner knob
on my stereo to find:
A nice smooth flowing daydreamy ambient pulse at 88.1 FM, lovely but not
quite right, I moved up to 92.5fm to find groovey ambient trip hop, a little
further at 97.3 I found Beautifully vocal house.  Just when I hit the coast
and the roads started to wind, Ahnon turned to to 100.5 where we found a nice
driving deep house sound, but that wasn't enough! I need 103.1, they were
playing the sweetest goa I ever heard! !/2 hour of that and I was ready for
...  you get the idea.
And that was just FM
Dreamin On,
-StEvEo

remaining tickets for the show.

Date: Fri, 21 Jun 1996 03:42:39 -0400
From: "Jason C. Lundy" <104242.1233@compuserve.com>
Subject: The Lounge...a good time had by all
Cc: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <199606210343_MC1-57E-B869@compuserve.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Good day,

Hadn't been to the Lounge in a month or so.

It had all of the main components to be a really cool midweek after hours
club. Nice sound 
(even cloth soud baffles on the ceiling, to prevent that harsh bounceback
effect) ,comfy lounge
 booths and chairs, $2 pints of Guiness, and happy raver type people.

But the music had lacked any real inspiration on the nights that I had been
there (can't speak
for other nights). Wow what a difference! Conrad and Biojeff threw down
last night.

First time I've heard progressive house and trance intermixed for hours
here in Sacto. Most
of Sacto just doesn't get this stuff. Hard house and lots O beats are the
main diet ravers
 sustain themselves on.

I'M A TRANCEHEAD!

Sacramento's conservative (Gotta have 8 hours sleep) mentality usually
empties most of a room
long before the last call at clubs, but wed. had about 20 or so out dacing
past 2 am. Many
 others were still hanging out in booths talking to their friends.
   
For a club, especially in Sacto, this has a really nice vibe to it. I think
I'll try and make it out
 there more often.

So if your on the list, and want see the face behind the machine; mail me
about a wed. and I'll
make it a point to be there.  

Same Bat Time...
          Same Bat channel...
                                          Jason

Subject: NRR..Good laugh
Date: Fri, 21 Jun 1996 08:00:28 -0700
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Subject: 52 Things to do on an elevator
     1. Make race car noises when anyone gets on or off.

     2. Blow your nose and offer to show the contents of your kleenex to
        other passengers.

     3. Grimace painfully while smacking your forehead and muttering:
        "Shut up, dammit, all of you just shut UP!"

     4. Whistle the first seven notes of "It's a Small World"
        incessantly.

     5. Sell Girl Scout cookies.

     6. On a long ride, sway side to side at the natural frequency of the
        elevator.

     7. Shave.

     8. Crack open your briefcase or purse, and while peering inside ask:
        "Got enough air in there?"

     9. Offer name tags to everyone getting on the elevator. Wear yours
        upside-down.

     10. Stand silent and motionless in the corner, facing the wall,
         without getting off.

     11. When arriving at your floor, grunt and strain to yank the doors
         open, then act embarrassed when they open by themselves.

     12. Lean over to another passenger and whisper: "Noogie patrol
         coming!"

     13. Greet everyone getting on the elevator with a warm handshake and
         ask them to call you Admiral.

     14. One word: Flatulence!

     15. On the highest floor, hold the door open and demand that it stay
         open until you hear the penny you dropped down the shaft go
"plink"
         at the bottom.

     16. Do Tai Chi exercises.

     17. Stare, grinning, at another passenger for a while, and then
         announce: "I've got new socks on!"

     18. When at least 8 people have boarded, moan from the back: "Oh,
         not now, damn motion sickness!"

     19. Give religious tracts to each passenger.

     20. Meow occassionally.

     21. Bet the other passengers you can fit a quarter in your nose.

     22. Frown and mutter "gotta go, gotta go" then sigh and say "oops!"


     23. Show other passengers a wound and ask if it looks infected.

     24. Sing "Mary had a little lamb" while continually pushing buttons.

     25. Holler "Chutes away!" whenever the elevator descends.

     26. Walk on with a cooler that says "human head" on the side.

     27. Stare at another passenger for a while, then announce "You're
         one of THEM!" and move to the far corner of the elevator.

     28. Burp, and then say "mmmm...tasty!"

     29. Leave a box between the doors.

     30. Ask each passenger getting on if you can push the button for
         them.

     31. Wear a puppet on your hand and talk to other passengers "through"
it.

     32. Start a sing-along.

     33. When the elevator is silent, look around and ask "is that your
         beeper?"

     34. Play the harmonica.

     35. Shadow box.

     36. Say "Ding!" at each floor.

     37. Lean against the button panel.

     38. Say "I wonder what all these do" and push the red buttons.

     39. Listen to the elevator walls with a stethoscope.

     40. Draw a little square on the floor with chalk and announce to the
         other passengers that this is your "personal space."

     41. Bring a chair along.

     42. Take a bite of a sandwich and ask another passenger: "Wanna see
         wha in muh mouf?"

     43. Blow spit bubbles.

     44. Pull your gum out of your mouth in long strings.

     45. Announce in a demonic voice: "I must find a more suitable host
         body."

     46. Carry a blanket and clutch it protectively.


     47. Make explosion noises when anyone presses a button.

     48. Wear "X-Ray Specs" and leer suggestively at other passengers.

     49. Stare at your thumb and say "I think it's getting larger."

     50. If anyone brushes against you, recoil and holler "Bad touch!"

     51. Jump up and down as the elavator is moving and say "I wonder how
long it will hold"

    52. Make farting noises with your mouth and say " Damn, I knew I
shouldn't have ate those beans this morning."


I hope you enjoyed it.

Tim (knucklehead)

something
going or have any broadcast, technical experience ?

what i saw 
in that movie "Pump up the volume".
Yeah man, lets get together and put a big sfraves transmitter on the top of
Twin peaks !
Is this feasable ?

Yours (trying to escape generic FM land)

KironO

jan and mark wrote:

> 
> >facing the dj, it's the right speaker...
> >
> >hehehe :) and if there is no speaker on the dj's right, 
> >and say, a huge wall of speakers, 
> >then it's the far right side of the wall :)
> >
> >take care, and i will talk to you later!
> 
> What if the DJ is in the middle of the floor (i.e. That Gathering party a 
> few months back)?
> 
> -M
> 
>                             ***ASTRONOUT***
>                           sounds textures beats

in this case...as it were at the gathering...we usually decide wehter to
use the rite side of the turntables/dj area, or to find a pseudo rfs. by
this i mean that when you walk into the room and face the dj, thre should
be (or were at the gathering) a set of speakers at the rite side in the
far back. so that became our "rfs" for the nite. like i sad..in cases like
these we kinda play it by ear. ;)  

*bye*

sarvi

I think she's on the list and her mailbox is full.  The mail's not making
it to her box. Often schools' limits
to mailbox sizes are _much_ smaller than commercial providers, especially a K-12
school, and if she's getting all the sfraves mails, and maybe isn't checking
them...Hey school may be out and maybe their sys-admin sucks.
	Anyway, the only problem with this is that most/all people subscribed
should be getting these mails bounced back.  So I'm probably wrong :)  Maybe
the gremlins are only after you and me...
	In any case, I would say our list-keeper might want to remove her from
the list, maybe after contacting her.  She hasn't posted to say "Hey
it's me!!"... 

Ahhh,

Hello all you wonderful summer fun lovers!  This Friday is Gateway's 1 year
anniversary Light Summer Solstice Celebration.  The line-up is in order
starting at 1pm. ending at 10p.m. Conciousness Lab (ambient meditation) then,
Monty, Galen, Andre Lucero, Jon Williams, John Carel, and a short closing
ambient meditation.  We are encouraging everyone to bring some type of
creative exchange like games, food, drums, didjeridoos, smiles, friends,
anything to share and celebrate!  There will be volleyball, croquette,  kiddy
pools w/ water, and a special art area.  The park is in Oakland near the
airport and is beautiful.  Directions are:  Take 580 tward the Oakland
Airport, Exit Hagenburger Rd., make the 1st right onto Edgewater, go up 1/4
mile and turn left onto Pardee.  Pull into the dirt parking lot directly on
your right.  The path into the park is paved and marked. Come and play in the
sun on the day with the most light!

Subject: J0cKs?.?.?  
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

 I hope I did this right?!?>

         So I just started dancing n all a few months ago. I always new about
"raves" but  I just never had friends willing to go. Plus I had a girlfriend
(that probably wouldn't let me) and I had no clue how to dance (not like I do
now though). 
        From what I know, those were the good times. My sister and her
friends were always out all night and I had no clue where they went. Just
lately my sister told me about all of these things she did. She told me about
huge parties that were in an old drive in parking lot where people could play
nintendo up on the screens. They had killer music then, and we do now, but
the music was soon adopted by radio stations like wild 107 and others. 
         Things like this made "Raves" too popular. Hell. . . cool world had
someone passing out flyers to people leaving my high school parking lot after
school. People thought that they were all cool n all cuz they "Raved". The
next thing you knew. "Raves" were turning into a big drug fest where people
thought they had to do drugs, because that's what they thought "Raving" was. 
           Now I can't help but hate all of those people who shouldn't be
there with us. All of those guys who lean against the wall trying to look
hard. All of those jocks who go because they either think that there'll be an
"E" orgy, or they think that some chick on "E" is gonna de-virginize them. I
mean. . . the last party I went to, there was a fight!!!
I have never seen that before. My sister has never seen it happen. Neither
has her friends. "Raves" are turning into the popular "scene" for druggies,
drunks, and porn-stars.
           I'm not saying that "E" or Acid is bad. I'm just saying that
people who go to raves thinking they are supposed to get high just have the
wrong idea.
          Maybe I'm just getting upset about a good thing turning bad. 
          I don't think that there's any way to stop this from happening.
There really isn't.  Too many people want to make too much money out there.
That just sucks!
          Seriously speaking, we should be careful of who we tell about our
love to. You wouldn't tell a rapist where a school full of young, christian,
hard-bodied women was. . . would you? You have to keep it alive. Don't kill
it. Don't let it die. Just keep it happy and everything will be just fine.

                        HaVe A nICe dAy!.!.!.!

                   Aryck


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Jun 22 01:16:53 1996

X-Sender: enigma@best.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.2
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: George Feil <enigma@best.com>
Subject: review: Chemical Bros. fizzle @Trocadero 
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, I just got back from the Trocadero. My sentiments are with those
fellow ravers who stay away from clubs: I just got wind of what I had been
missing.

The crowd was largely devoid of vibe. There was a huge pack making vain
attempts to dance on the floor, and some truly wacky fashion statements. The
real party was happening upstairs. A few whisps of vibe wafted through the
area, disguised as pot smoke. Clubbers smoke way too much, compared to
ravers. Ah, I complain too much...back to the review.

The DJ's sucked big time. One of them even complained about not having a
monitor to mix with. The evening started with mostly gabber and jungle, then
turned to some house, and aimed towards technoland (i.e. Kraftwerk) when
they mercifully stopped.

The Brothers finally made it to the stage around 10:30. They started in for
just a few moments, when technical difficulties killed their set. After some
futzing around, the Brothers finally "worked it out", and started in. WAY to
much bass -- I mean, my throat was hurting from the bass action. The sound
was very distorted.

One of the sets they played was composed of the first few tracks of their
"Exit Planet Dust" CD, in exact order. The tunes sounded almost identical to
the CD. These guys ought to take some lessons from Gary Clail, the guru of
live mixing (check out some of the early Tackhead albums -- the stuff he did
10 years ago make this duo sound like amateurs by comparison).

Well, enough venting for now. Hope everyone enjoys the big show in Big Bear
tomorrow. I may end up heading over to Sunset on Sunday, then on to the
Fillmore on Monday, to get my rave appetite filled for the weekend.

P&L,
-G-

P.S. I finally bought my first PC, after sticking with employers' and
university eqipment all these years. I'll be tending to this page from home
mostly, with occasional peeks at work. [THX1138, if you think Windows '95
sucks for system administration and setup, you should try Windows NT -- an
adventure in frustration, especially on the hardware side!]

I understand how you might feel about this. You've come to realise the these parties and 
the ritual of dance mean more to you now because of the good times you've had and the 
wonderful memories from it that you carry with you. But when you see things that
disturb or make you angry like fights, people completely off their heads from 
drugs, or people who seem to not understand why or what it's all about i.e. 'jocks', you 
must allow them the same opportunity to learn from these events as you have. As we all 
have. The people attending these events make up a variety of backgrounds, cultures, 
lifestyles, and ideas. To give them the chance to learn from out-moded behaviors and 
thoughts, to explore the possibilities of new, more creative ways of expression, and to 
be in an environment conducive to change. The dance, the music, the people are those 
forces of change for even the most stubborn of temperment. It will be a struggle not to 
get angry over 'something good turning bad' but remember that these are learning 
experiences for everyone and perhaps with compassion for others, understanding of 
differences, and living life as the 'example' rather than as a 'reaction' -- we can all 
influence positive changes in the world around us. This is what actually keeps the scene 
alive as well the rest of humanity. Subside the fears and the anger, embrace the love 
and warmth of what we all share -- Life.

Peace be with always,
Tex


MXSNOWMAN@aol.com wrote:

>  I hope I did this right?!?>
> 
>          So I just started dancing n all a few months ago. I always new about

> nintendo up on the screens. They had killer music then, and we do now, but
> the music was soon adopted by radio stations like wild 107 and others.

> thought they had to do drugs, because that's what they thought "Raving" was.

[ to sfraves list ]

 Thanks to Claire , Andrew , John Carel, and everyone else who organized
the wonderful LIGHT Solstice event at the "emergency" Point Molate site
yesterday! Despite a rough start due to getting kicked out from the 
original Oakland site, the crew got things packed, moved, and set up in 
great time!

 Some memories -
* Mighty Dog! : There was this black and grey hound that was totally 
  obsessed with a black driftwood 2"x4"x5' plank. If anyone threw the
  plank into the cold cold bay, that mutt would throw himself out into
  the water after it. He(she?) would drag the damn board all about, pawing
  at it and growling and barking at its toy.

* Water guns! : With little blue handpistols and larger mini-soaker rifles.
  Despite the chilling breeze, some folks actually got into shootouts!

* Nice people! : Met some new folks , and put more faces to email names.
  Dance area density got to optimum around 7:30PM. Good feelings all
  around.

 Someone please post the sequence of DJs. 

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Intelligent thinking (is that redundant?) on the part of the Gateway crew
yesterday: while most parties at that park have the DJ table set near the
parking lot, the light crew put the decks near the water, which made for a
much nicer view for the dancers--instead of looking at parked cars as we
danced around, we all got to face the water and watch the sun go down.
  It was *so* much better that way... Sunset organizers, please take note!

see you all out there,
Timothy

Greeting everyone out there on sfraves.  Some of you may have read Steve's
note about me. . .and I thought a real introduction was in order. 
 My name is Phelps and although I have Sactown origins I spend a predominate
amout of time at Mills College in Oakland (where I go 8 months out of the
year) and bopping around Berkeley and SF.
I can totally relate to Eric P. Peterson's hunger for some good summer
parties.  Last year was an explosion of fun for me at Sunsets and other
outdoor celebrations.  It ended with a blast of a time at Burning Man (my
second year) with wonderful company like Steve, Rick Riffle, fellow new
member Jesse, and about a hundred other kindred spirits.
Last weekend's Orion was a good effort, but was a downer for many of the
people involved (including my little sister who never got there and I who got
there 10min. to shut down). Yesterday's Gateway Light Solstice party was a
(chilly) blast once it finally got settled into a location. . .although Brad
from Consciousness Lab did an awsome set at the (busted) first spot.
I'm looking forward to seeing and meeting you all at parties in the future. .

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Sat, 22 Jun 1996 15:43:54 -0800

From: anarch@scruznet.com (Anarch)
Subject: Chemical Brothers
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Tremendously mediocre.  Nothing outright bad, but disappointing all around.
I would have had a much better time listening to a good DJ spinning their
records.  For now, they're definitely a group for the studio--they showed
little capacity to improvise or innovate in a live context, playing most of
their album stuff pretty straight and, in the process, running smack into
the limits of the restricted sonic palette available onstage.  Lacking the
opportunities of the studio for layering and manipulation, they apparently
compensated with overdriven PA rather than working within or around the
limits of the setup, producing a monotonous sound with way too much hiss
and boom, and not enough thump, for my taste.  Not that there weren't any
good bits at all--I enjoyed the ten minutes or so around the time the
visuals shifted from monochrome to color the most--but it was a drag on the
whole, especially after paying $15.  And they only played for an hour or
so.  And, of course, it was at the Trocadero--effing *packed*, as always
(I'm positive they let in more than the Fire Marshal allows for that
space), and packed with a Terminator crowd to boot (Deathguild would have
been tolerable).

Thank god I left and crawled around the corner and up the street to Light
in the Addict, which made my night.  A bit sparsely attended, but all cool
people and all kickass tunes (who was that on from 1-3 or so?).  Took off
around 4 and headed down to warm myself at the BASS fire for a bit, but
despite great spinning the music was a little too head and not enough body
for me, so I moved on down to close things out with Tracy and Rob at Rain
Dance's clifftop solstice celebration.  Nice, but a little too relaxed...I
want to be AWAKENED when the sun's coming up.

anarch@scruznet.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Jun 22 18:45:00 1996

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

    I am New to the list (1 week) and was attempting to comply with ettiquete
and not post for the obligatory two week break in period when I read the
"Jocks" post.  I have been attending house parties (raves) since '91 and have
been to them in L.A., San Diego, San Francisco,  Sydney Australia, and
Vancouver Canada.  Every scene is a little different as far as attitude is
concerned (San Fran. is the best by far).  What I like about the scene is the
wide assortment of people that attend and the acceptance that is exibited by
(most) people.  The author of "Jocks" seems to be missing this attribute by a
wide margin.  I don't pay much attention to the fashions prevalent at the
parties I usually throw on a pair of jeans and a tee-shirt and my Docs and
go.  I am much more interested in the party than trying to fit in.  I also
stay in shape.  And when I tire of dancing or overheat sometimes I even lean
against a wall to watch everyone enjoy themselves (what a horrible crime).
 Could I be one of the people the author has such a problem with?  I thought
the rave scene was beyond labeling people by their appearance only.  This is
high school mentality.  I am drawn to raves as a philosophy major because of
the good emotions and attitudes radiated by my fellow human beings regardless
of their color, sexual orientation, or fashion sense.  Violence at raves of
course is intolerable but I must say it is an aberration (except maybe in
L.A.).  I would like to extend an invitation to the author to go to a party
with me and maybe he will understand how off base he is.  In fact I would
like to go to a party tonight and my friends are busy with work e.t.c.   What
do you say?

























                                                                         Jeff

> One of the sets they played was composed of the first few tracks of their
> "Exit Planet Dust" CD, in exact order. The tunes sounded almost identical to
> the CD. These guys ought to take some lessons from Gary Clail, the guru of
> live mixing (check out some of the early Tackhead albums -- the stuff he did
> 10 years ago make this duo sound like amateurs by comparison).

WORD! I had the luck of seeing a Gary Clail and TackHead shows (w/
Andrian Sherwood on  the mix, natch) in London and Bristol back around
88-89 (same year that I discovered "raving" by accident while
vacationing in Ibiza!). Very excellent LIVE shows indeed!

(And, b/t/w the real guru of live mixing behind "Gary Clail" or
"Tackhead" is Adrian Sherwood...)

As someone that got into techno/rave from the industrial/funk side of
things (e.g. Tack>>Head, Fats Comet, Skinny Puppy etc.) I'd have to say
that we haven't necessarily come that great a distance in the last 10
years. And unfortunately, few have been able to transition their studio
based art into live performance (this goes both for techno and rap
too).

PS: no I didn't go to the Chemical Bros show... i don't like the Troc,
and I hadn't heard that many glowing reviews about past Chemical Bros
shows. I like the Chemical Brothers ok, but it's not like they're going
into my personal pantheon of great musicians.

See you all at the Orbital/Underworld show -- I'm expecting it to be good!

PS: also coming up and hopefully a good "funk" show -- The Meters at
the Fillmore. Hope they got the original lineup. I've heard talk that
Leo Nocentelli (guitarist) and George Porter (bass) have gone their
separate ways and are fronting their own bands. Hopefully Art Neville
(keyboards, yeah, it's the Neville Brother's Art Neville) and one of
the usual lineup of funky New Orleans drummers (e.g. Russel Battiste)
will be there. Anybody know for sure?

DRUGGIES AND GANGSTAS HAVE BEEN INVADING ON THE RAVE SCENE SINCE IT
STARTED.  BUT DO NOT WORRY IT COMES IN WAVES.  IF YOU DO WHAT YOU LOVE AND
STICK WITH IT THEN IT WILL PAY OFF.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Jun 23 17:16:56 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA17534; Sun, 23 Jun 1996 17:16:56 -0700

Received: from [206.5.32.34] by mailhub.manual3.com
 with SMTP (Apple Internet Mail Server 1.0); Sun, 23 Jun 1996 17:17:42 -0800
X-Sender: nathan_moser@mailhub.manual3.com
Message-Id: <v02130501adf38cf2f09c@[206.5.32.34]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 23 Jun 1996 17:17:38 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: nathan_moser@manual3.com (Nathan Moser)
Subject: Sankofa shredded my knees!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I've been thinking for a while that this scene needs something to shake it
up. Something people can love or hate but not ignore. Even the music's gone
tepid, it seems, so as to lull people gently through an e trip chosen with
great discretion and care. I could be wrong, of course, but I think that -
with the exception of Archimedes - no one has ever come to great insights
while in a bubble bath. Most of the UG parties I've been to lately have
been as guilty of this as the commercial ones.

Rabbit in Moon at Sankofa this morning is exactly what we need more of. The
two-man, musician-and-random-freak team was clever, sophomoric, brilliant,
silly, stupid, relentless, endearing, beautiful, and I loved every second
of it. The music itself plodded a few times, but there were some great
moments, not the least of which was a theremin with some phat bass. The
random freak's costumes and props were inspired, I thought. I definitely
want to try the face mask/grinding wheel combo for myself sometime!

I'm sure at least one person was miffed that the all the crowd's energy was
suddenly focused on the stage and not on the crowd itself, but Rabbit in
the Moon clearly took a pathetically limpid commercial event and turned it
on its head. After they closed off their act, the next DJ (who was??) took
the energy and ran with it, throwing down some of the harder tracks I've
heard in months. When we left at 6AM or so, the place was as populated as
it was at 2:30, and was going off in a much bigger way.

So now my golden rule of "an event's worthwhileness is in inverse
proportion to its cost" is shattered.

-nate

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Jun 23 23:38:34 1996

From: phred@well.com
Received: from well.com (phred@well.com [206.15.64.10]) by mh1.well.com (8.7.5/8.7.5) with SMTP id XAA14621; Sun, 23 Jun 1996 23:38:31 -0700 (PDT)
Received: (from phred@localhost) by well.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id XAA01264; Sun, 23 Jun 1996 23:38:26 -0700
Date: Sun, 23 Jun 1996 23:38:26 -0700
Message-Id: <199606240638.XAA01264@well.com>
To: nw-raves@hyperreal.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: rolling along
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

We had a pretty fair start for audio.cafe last Wednesday night at the
Paris Theatre in Portland.  I think nearly 100 people came through at
some point, though some only stayed briefly.  Another one scheduled
for July 3, we'll go a little later due to it being the start of the
long holiday.  DJs will be J Mystic (Jeremy), RobP and myself, as it
currently stands.  

Yesterday we had wonderful time at Rooster Rock state park at the
mouth of the Columbia Gorge doing the second Saturdaze event.  The
weather was changeable but mostly very nice.  We set up in a park area
between I-84 and the river, right at the foot of the bluff that forms
Crown Point, one of *the* scenic vistas in Oregon.  We had a nice view
of a small waterfall off the cliff, and the park virtually to ourselves.
The rangers came by and visited, said we really shouldn't be doing this
but turn it down, so we did and everyone was happy.  Not much attendance,
about 30 in all I think, but a really nice one.  As for music, I started
followed by Dubs, Jeremy, Rob and Randy.  

I went to the Mecca party co-sponsored by XLR8R and Prescription Records
last night.  Amazingly enough, it was at the old Neighbors of Woodcraft
hall (now called the "Tiffany Center" for reasons I do not understand).
I say amazingly because that is where I did the final concert of my
promotion career in 1982, featuring the as-yet-unknown Nu Shooz.  
It's a nice and kind of stuffy place as far as ambience with a big
hall where the main sound was.  Up on the stage were Mike Stevens,
Diz, Johnny Fiasco and Rawno, and upstairs in a side room were the
trip hop/ambient/dub/whatever toonz -- Professor Andrew Smith at the
mixing console when I visited.  I would estimate maybe 500 or 600 paid
admissions, which means the promoters probably took a bath, the place
was really about half full.  The sound and lights were adequate but
not great.  The playing was reasonably interesting, though I can't tell
you how many people told me that Derrick Carter was spinning the set
before Johnny Fiasco's.  The man's name is Diz and he was doing it well.

I had a moderately good time, and I suppose that $20 for this lineup
and a nice place is comparable to $13 for a dirty warehouse, but there
just didn't seem to be much excitement about the whole affair.  Then
again, that's about par for the large gatherings.

phred

==You know for the life of me I can't figure out why anyone would want to 
drive several hours out in to the middle of ==nowhere, leaving any vestige
of civilization, into heat, dust, mud, without any place to take a proper 
bath, and with ==a bunch of like-minded people who are similarly off their 
collective rockers. Ooohhh I can't wait! :-)
==
==                                        Black Adder


I take it you don't like the great outdoors very much.

Most people are drawn to this event, and nature in general, due to this
lack of civilization. There is something primal
about having to survive on what you have brought into this desolation.
Black Rock also forces you to focus upon
yourself and those who have accompanied you there, for there are none of
life's daily trials to distract. In fact, there
is nothing at all that has not been lugged there by some individual, for
some purpose of survival or entertainment.
I feel that this focus, though short lived, is much needed in many people's
lives. I often leave the wilderness with
a new found perspective on my life or something that has been troubling me.
I also believe it is healthy to make a 
connection with nature; for we are all natural beings. 

Not to mention the sheer abundance of creativity that is so much a part
this particular gathering. Wow!


Take care,
                  Jason

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Jun 24 09:01:08 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id JAA04436; Mon, 24 Jun 1996 09:01:08 -0700

Date: Mon, 24 Jun 1996 09:01:01 -0700 (PDT)
From: John Deatherage <dwarzau@ns.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Sankofa
Message-ID: <Pine.HPP.3.91.960624085203.2479B-100000@hornet.ns.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hmmmm.... where do I start...

Got in for phree (thank God) and went in to check out the space.  I don't 
think I could actually *see* the other side of the warehouse.   It was 
HUGE!  This was around 1pm, and there was someone playing Josh Wink's 
remix of Moby's "Bring Back my Happiness"... when the song hit the break, 
the bass was booming and it really sounded like muddled garbage.

The DJs that followed... Jungle - didn't work, and morning trace garbage 
for awhile... Then DJ Dan went on and played a boring, uninspired set.  
Rabbit in the Moon was cool, although a lot of it was DAT.  I fell asleep 
near the end of their performance, and woke up to Doug E. Fresh and MC 
Ricky D :) and noticed Terry Mullan was on!

Well, I think they did a pretty good job with everything, although the DJ 
lineup was in about the worst order possible.  I still had lots of fun 
(got my sfraves laminate finally :) met TONS of cool people and somehow 
made it out alive.  They only needed about 2000 people to break even, and 
they probably had about 4 or 5?  Really, if they could've filled the 
party earlier and put the right DJs on at the right times that could've 
been one of the best parties of the year.  Too bad my girlfriend wanted 
to leave in the morning and I missed most of Terry's set.  That about 
sums it all up! :)

John

Folks, let us be careful about "labeling."  It is too easy to neatly box=20
a human being into a certain category and then write them off.  I would=20
hope that we can appreciate each human being for their individuality,=20
instead of putting them down with labels.  This is taking the easy way=20
out, instead of attempting to see the person in his/her entirity.

On Mon, 24 Jun 1996, Reagan Reid wrote:
> 
>   I was at the Marina until 5. Did alot of people show up at Pt. Molate 
> afterwards?? Sunset was looking purrrty good when I was leaving:).

Hi Reagan et al,

Sunset was definitely purrrty great yesterday... I had a blast!  Point
Molate was even more beautiful than usual (crystal clear across the bay,
sunset went all red and purple, ahhhh).  There really was NO reason the
cops had to break it up at the marina, but luckily almost everyone showed
up at the new location.  A very friendly and happy crowd.  We were there
'till it ended around 10! :) :) 

Mantra was also really great last night.  Now *that* is my kind of trance. 
Fast, fast, fast.  :) :) :)  If only I could've stayed past 1am....it
seemed to be getting even better.  The organizers do a really great job
with this one... nice decorations, lots of black lights, water galore, and
GREAT MUSIC.  I like the space at cat's grill too. 

Coming soon -- my web page with pix from new moon, the last two sunsets,
and more.  :)

Hugs,
Paul

I am glad to hear that some people had a good time at Sankofa.  I 
contemplated going, but after I called the voice mail on Saturday night, 
I decided to stay home.  The voice-mail was pretentious and all about how 
we should just LOVE going to their parties.  Then the woman made (my 
impression) a sarcastic joke about "bring your harmony with you", then 
she and her friends busted out laughing in the back ground.  Whatever. 
I'll save my money for something more worthwhile.  I feel no need to 
support a group who thinks I should be dying to go to their party because 
it is the biggest baddest shit around town.  Sorry, I'll pass.

great PR)

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Sunset started out beautifully at the Berkeley Marina.  Nature,
sunshine, house music, ahh.  Tone gave me the Haiku trophy;
the awards ceremony was low-key mainly because I couldn't fit my
acceptance speech into 5-7-5 syllables.  Rick bestowed a
Consciousnes Research Labs tape on me.  Haven't listened to the whole
thing yet, but we like it so far; nice relaxing ambient
with just enough quirky sounds and subtle rhythms to keep it 
interesting.  Thanks! 

We were riding the vibe nicely, but fate had other plans.  Something 
about a rookie cop who didn't know that it was cool to
just look the other way.  He/she Called back for
instructions, and well, once you have to ask...  This is what I
heard, anyway.  Hope we'll be able to return in the future.

We felt kinda down at that point - a close friend of ours is sick
and dying - so we went down by the water and thought about him and
stuff.  Finally decided that dancing at Pt. Molate would be the healthy
thing to do.

There, DJ Unknown was spinning some glurpy acid with the kind of
sounds that every kid with hir first analog synth loves to make
in the bedroom.  Kinda fun for a bit, but didn't really create
the kind of groove I like to dance to.  Other's were digging 
it though.  The sunset was very Orangey and beautiful.  By the time
Garth came on, bodies were smothering Pacific's sound system, so it
was hard to really get into it.  Nevertheless, it was great to be out
with the tribe.

Oh, yeah, got our tickets for next week's Sunset boat party.  The last 
one was completely nuts.  Sadly, Freedom will not be at the Livermore
motorcycle racetrack.  Will still be outdoors though, and Martin
promises the same organ-rupturing sound system as last year.  The
vibe might be better at Harmony or whatever that weekend, but I just 
can't resist the big-killer-sound-system-outdoors thing.  Unfortunately,
ever since we watched that silly movie, Braveheart, we can't think about
this party in quite the same way - thanks to the final scene where
Mel Gibson responds to being disembowled by shouting "FREEDOM!!!!".

Lee
_________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com

From: "roger kumar" <rkumar@umr.edu>

X-Www-Page: http://www.umr.edu/~rkumar/
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

:)

After a long meandering walk through Berkeley, we arrived at the very 
beautiful Berkeley Marina and Sunset, with four Rave Virgins in tow. 
Things were perfect at the Marina: a nice-sized crowd, a great view of 
the sun shimmering on the bay, the city, the hills, and stuff. I brought 
my bubble machine along and managed to get it working for about five 
minutes before it died from too much use. Met Justin and it was very good 
to see him. Then, three of the Rave Virgins decided to leave and that was 
sad. Then the ugly Berkeley Police came and stopped it all, beacuse of 
lack of $10 permit. I tried offering a cop the 10 bucks, but he called my 
clueless and explained to me how I need to give the $10 to someone else. 
Then another cop started babbling how he was around in the sixties', and 
how they had free concerts at Haight, and how we should get some corporate 
sponsorship, and how there was never going to be a Rave Party without 
E. So Justin, Carlos, Ruth, and I went to a really great place to eat in 
Emeryville before arriving at the backup location at Point Molate, which 
was also beautiful, and filled with many many people. Met Robert and a 
lot of other sfravers, and had a great time and enjoyed the red and 
orange and purple sunset. I was very glad Ruth, the first-time-raver (but 
not the last) enjoyed herself; she had a great time dancing and drawing. 
Too bad the others decided to leave early, but that was somewhat 
expected. see everyone at the obital/underworld show tonight. 

-- 
pJou_|        			 pgp encrypted fone and mail accepted
    _l				 rkumar@lbl.gov        rkumar@umr.edu

Hello dear friends!

Seems like every time I talk about raves with my roommate, John, he comes
to the same conclusions.  He says that if I'm not there (at a party) to
either make money or meet women, then I'm wasting my time.  The last time
we talked about this, he said that I shouldn't spend my time hanging around
"teeny-boppers bouncing around on e."  Can you believe that sh*t?  He says
that I should be spending my time in the (get this) clubs around downtown
San Jose, meeting women.  Just the thought of that sends off all kinds of
warning bells and whistles in my mind!
I asked John if he'd ever been to a rave, to which he of course replied
"No."  I said "Then you're not in a position to make these kinds of
judgments."  He agreed with me, but every time the topic comes up, he
launches into the same sermon.  He has no idea of the intense spiritual
fulfillment and the wonderful friendships I find in the course of
celebrating life through dance.  Although I know that I shouldn't let what
he says get to me, it still does, and sometimes it gets me down.  Can
someone, anyone, out there please lift me up?  Can I get a witness?

Love,

Eric

> we talked about this, he said that I shouldn't spend my time hanging around
> "teeny-boppers bouncing around on e."  Can you believe that sh*t?  He says
> that I should be spending my time in the (get this) clubs around downtown
> San Jose, meeting women.  Just the thought of that sends off all kinds of
> warning bells and whistles in my mind!
> I asked John if he'd ever been to a rave, to which he of course replied
> "No."  I said "Then you're not in a position to make these kinds of
> judgments."  He agreed with me, but every time the topic comes up, he
> launches into the same sermon.  He has no idea of the intense spiritual
> fulfillment and the wonderful friendships I find in the course of
> celebrating life through dance.  Although I know that I shouldn't let what
> he says get to me, it still does, and sometimes it gets me down.  Can
> someone, anyone, out there please lift me up?  Can I get a witness?
> 
> Love,
> 
> Eric
> 
> 
>

From: Tony Rose <trose@violet.berkeley.edu>

Subject: ORGANIC review
In-Reply-To: <Pine.BSD/.3.91.960624131339.27448B-100000@value.net>

WOW!!!!!!!!!this was the most massive I am still so spun from the whole
thing...It all started with lunch with my friends Dave (on this list)
willow the goddess and my bro phillip at lunch on friday...we started tlk
ing about the party and decided what the hell...we gotta go. so I took
daves car to the shop...and we found out it had a busted head OH NO! then
my bro got fired from his job that afternoon so he could go!! so we rented
a car and left from berkeley around 8:00 pm, arrived in LA around
1:00...Dave drives like a madman...110 mph the whole way! after finding a
wonderful inspiring friend of willows to crash at at 3:30 we partied with
her all night and day while picking up goddies for the party! I got
really baked that day and took a walk around venice beach with my
bro...what a trip! LA is the strngest f*****g place! we were wearing
cutoffs and t-shirts and we felt realy out of place! smoe guy walkee
by us and said "your not in kansas anymore" HUH!!!!! I trhinki there
is some rule in LA that you are not allowed to go in publilc unless
you have fresh undies cologne and look absolutely marvelous! but
anyways lorie hooked us up rightously with the best juice shakes in the
whole world before we left. hopefully she will be coming up here real soon
so we can show her the SF scene!...so we left around 6:00 to the
party...on the way up the mountain we picked up four ravers who had lost
their spaceship due to technical difficulties...the vibe was tertiffic,
everyone was so excited and happy...we finally got into the place and it
was a wonderful site...the main laser was shooting all over the main stage
spelling out gigantically the words ORGANIC and other cool
patterns...about this point things start geting a litle blurry...meat beat
was kind of weird...their industrial roots were showing through...we
walked around and danced and talked and wandered all over ...there were
these glasses that you put on "brain food" that blink lights and for a
buck you could sit and trip on them al\s long as you wanted shit...what a
mind trip!!!!....finally the ORB came on...that was the highlight just
pure mind fucking...
	the sound system was teriffic, the only annoying thing was the
radio guy coming on and introdicing orbital..."HI is everyone having fun
YEAH...IM balah blah from blah blah blah radio station balh blah blah
blah" and the mostly on the main stager the music seemed to me like more
listen and be awed more than we are going to build this thing until the
whole valley exsplodes in mad dance! kind of like a cross between
lollapalooza and a rave.
	to end the story the party ended around six and we partied in the
lot until around 9:00 and then gave this poor fella a ride to la because
his ride left him htere! but he was such a cool guy really styled us out
the whole way (N20) back to la! then we drove home...got stuck in traffic
for about 2 hours and made it back to berkeley around 10:30 last night!!!
3 hours of sleep the whole weekend!!!!
	we all had the time of our lives!!
* * ** *** ***** ******** ************* ******************

There will be a general meeting for anyone who wants to get involved in the
second BBQ & Beats party.  Tim and I will be points of contact for this
one, but we need input and help to pull it off.

Tim kicked out a date, but we might rethink that, nothing is set in stone yet.

Anyway, the meeting will be at my house this coming Thursday (6/27).  I
live in Noe Valley, SF, and am accessible by BART or public transport.
Please email me for directions, etc, if you can make it.

Three things that will make this meeting a good thing for you:

1)  You get to see how parties develop from the ground up, including DJ
selection (a fun topic indeed ;^), search for a sound system, and basic
principles in crowd control.

2)  You get to meet my kitten Barb!

3)  You'll be at the source for FnF patches and thus won't have to chase me
at a Sunset (or win a haiku contest) to get yours.  ;^)

Let me know if you can make it.

Tony

P.S. If someone wants to let Leslie know, that would be a good thing...

P.P.S.  This meeting will be BYOB.

AMEN, BROTHER E!

My buddy Sean spouts the exact same crap.  It wasn't until I got a mutual 
friend of ours to go to one and she came back talking about how much fun it 
was that he softened his tune a little.  He's actually considering letting 
us drag him kicking and screaming to one (?!).  I'm SO tired of mainstream 
club crowds.  I like to go to an event with the primary intention of just 
plain having fun.  Then if I meet someone I just happen to want to see again 
outside that venue, that's different, but it's not my primary mission.

Your friend needs to attend a couple of these events, and he needs to adopt 
the correct mindset before going -- that of having fun with like-minded people.

Good luck, my brother in raving...

S

To: Wumpus 99 <erase99@sirius.com>
From: johnsin@xanadu.cyborganic.net (John Drefahl)
Subject:  Intro/Orbital/Underworld Meeting place
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hmm.. Maybe I will check that out with my friend forrest.. First rave thing
I have done since I got here.

Okay, here is the deal.. I will be wearing my massive jacket.  Easy enough
to find me because I will be the only one with a massive jacket..  So if I
am not there cause I am late or what not.. just look out.. I am friendly,
and have no problem with people who I don't know introduce themselves to
me.

SanFran, fun to be here.  Great place..

A little about myself for you kids in Sfrave world.

My name is john, I am from milwaukee.  While I was living in milwaukee (20
years of my life) I got pretty into the midwest rave scene.  Well most of
you will probably go, "pfft, midwest!", but as some of you transplants
know.. the midwest scene is strong and continuously growing.

Milwaukee wasn't a bad place to be.. I mean, shit, Gabber calls milwaukee
home, as well as Drop Bass records, and Massive Magazine.  You have Chicago
2 hours south which is the birthplace of house music and the home of many
famous house labels.  About 6 hours East and around lake michigan you have
Detroit, do I have to say much more.  So I was in the thick of the culture.
Chicago also was Jungle's third town.. Toronto being second, and
Londontown being the home.  So I guess you can see, I was pretty much in
Technoland.

Now I am here, I see a lot of different types of people, a whole new
attitude towards the music.. So forgive me if I seem a bit out of place in
your scene.. But mine was different.. and well, I got to adjust..

While I was in Milwaukee I worked very heavily on Massive Magazine.  Now
you don't know what Massive is, lets just say that it is our equivilent to
XLR8R.  We are working on issue 14 right now, and we have a circulation of
10-15,000 per issue.  The west coast was not a big distribution point for
us because we really didn't know anyone out there.  But now I am here, you
will surely see massive...   We mostly concentrated on the East Coast and
Midwest..  15,000 copies go fast believe me.

Anyways, I started as a designer there, and now I strictly on do the Jungle
section and some web page stuff.  I can't really do much since I am here
now.  Ohh well..

Anyways, there is alittle about me..  See you tonight.. and have a good time..

John aka johnsin massive..

remember jungle...

>ok.. i have agreed to meet up with Jess and KaySee at the entrance to the
>dance floor at 9:00 sharp.
>so, if anyone wants to meet more people, just come over then!
>since half the list seems to be going, we should meet many new people. :)

Find money and love in a San Jose club? BS! You're roommate is the one
wasting his time! You gotta grab a tube of Rogaine and read the Wall Street
Journal cover to cover. You won't find the right mate till you've made your
first your first million, and you can benchpress twice your weight. Forget
your transcendental experiences, brother, they're all a drug-induced haze.
Once you experience your first IPO, you'll know I'm right. Realize that
country music has changed a lot over the past few years, and you'll be a
much happier person. Really.

planet, like being plunged into the frenzied ritual of some alien 
techno-primitive culture from the pages of Heavy Metal.  Imagine the 
savage rites of pre-Christian Europe times an underground voodoo

electric noise.  Something like that, anyway.

I'm going to crash worship!. 
 
I've heard nothin' but FUCKIN' AWESOME reviews about this band.   They have
a HELL of a reputation at Mardi Gras. 
 
I've never seen their "SHOW", but.... 
 
Last time I was down to Mardi Gras, their show was cancelled by the police
so they proceded to protest by leading a sort of "Running of the Bull"
through the crowded streets of Mardi Gras. 
 
I'll never forget... I was standing on the corner of the Decatur district
and before I know what the hall was going on... I was flattened and almost
run over by a   stampede of fire jugglers, flame throwers and other various
wild costumed individuals parading a chariot which held a mockery of the
mardi gras princess.  He/She was less than appealing... I might add. 
 
Police on foot and horse proceded to chase the growing stampede of Crash
Worship fans and random followers who thought it might be fun to join the
primal race... until finally it ended in a large chaotic celebration of
drumming, performing, yelling, etc. 
 
My friends and I will never forget that!  And I'm goin' tomorrow... 
Anyone want to come with me? 
 
 
--erik  415-337-6666
