> On Sun, 23 Jun 1996, Terry Huntington wrote:
> 
> > THIS HAS BEEN A PROBLEM SINCE 1991,  IT IS NOTHING NEW.  JOCKS AND
> > DRUGGIES AND GANGSTAS HAVE BEEN INVADING ON THE RAVE SCENE SINCE IT
> > STARTED.  BUT DO NOT WORRY IT COMES IN WAVES.  IF YOU DO WHAT YOU LOVE AND
> > STICK WITH IT THEN IT WILL PAY OFF.
> > 


Hi all!

 Just my 2 cents here; Raves are essientially public events. Get used to 
dealing with the public; it is the real world in which we live in. I 
would think that if raves got so exclusive (like a country club or 
republican party) that they would eventually die. Lets face it; one of 
the most appealing aspects of raves comes from other people being there. 
I know I would get bored (quickly!) if I saw the same happy smiley faces 
all the time (happy but bored). I thrive on the challenges in life and 
one of the biggest challenges is (for me) getting along with those who 
are disagreeable to me (for whatever reasons).

 Many of those that some have mentioned as disagreeable (jocks, druggies) 
have some very loveable, endearing qualities. The challenge I take is to 
draw those qualities out of them. Sometimes the best way is by setting an 
example of acceptance and friendly, loving vibes.

 Of course sometimes problems arise when people try to take advantage; 
this why knowing your personal boundries is good.

 I'm sorry if I sound kinda preachy and I don't mean to sound like these 
issues are easy for me. I struggle plenty with rude, inconsiderate folks. 
I just try to learn and gain from any situation I'm in. Sometimes it 
works and sometimes it don't.

Peace out

Ran

            ( and on the eigth day God created the beat )
                            /
                      -=*=-/
                        ~

Cybertribe,

Hi, my name is Marshal Villarosa, but most people know me as Mars.  I 
live in New Jersey about 30 minutes from Manhattan, but I've been out to 
the Bay Area twice in the last two months.  The first time was to spin at 
a party called Lucky Charms that the Bagok Tribe threw, the second time 
was for a business meeting with Pacifc Bell (but got to check out a party 
at People's Park in Berkley and "Dune" put on by Funky Tekno Tribe in 
Oakland).

I'm a systems engineer by day for Lucent Technologies, one of AT&T's 
spinoff companies.  By night, I'm a DJ and rave promoter and have been in 
the rave scene on the East Coast since the Spring of 1992 (Stormrave of 
Brooklyn & Catastrophic of DC).  I've been heavily involved with the 
NE-Raves and NYC-Raves e-mail lists, and I think I know a couple of you 
who used to be out in the NYC area.  I've been DJing since 1990 and spin 
trance which I have just started producing as well.

I love the San Fran vibe, though, and it's been influencing my musical 
tastes and changed my concept of what the rave scene could be like (the 
Organic Party I went to in Golden Gate Park).  I've met some awesome 
people out there, and have really wanted to see them again.  So, with 
that said, I'll be in San Fran this weekend, from Thursday night to 
Sunday night.  I'd love to meet, dance, and share the vibe with you.  
Send me some mail on how we could do that!

Peace, love, and Unity,
DJ Mars - NJ Underground

=] Keep your smile smilin'!!! =]

mailto:mars@hyperreal.com
mailto:xmars@haven.ios.com
http://haven.ios.com/~xmars/
http://hyperreal.com/~mars/

I wish I'd stuck around for Underworld, but I had to work this morning! 
But Orbital WAS the group I went to see and they were quite impressive.
Dealing the crowd a fine mixture of old and new material they rode
break-beat dragon for what seemed like hours, only letting the energy drop
between songs (which I didn't really like). Kudos to the crowd- I was so
happy to see so many smiling faces on a Monday! 
*sigh* the only drawback was the sound- definately muddled at points and
sometimes lacking the ribcage-rattling bass I crave. But otherwise a fine
Monday night!

-Alex

Alex-

 My original intention was to also see Orbital.  I figured that Underworld 
would just be an added bonus.  I have since been converted!  Underworld played 
some of the greatest music I've ever heard.  It did seem like alot of people 
left after Orbital played, but for those who stuck around, Underworld was 
top-notch.

-Todd

PS- Work is much more interesting when you have partied all night long, not 
slept at all, and you begin to listen to your Orbital and Underworld CD's with 
a large grin on your face!!!

induced insomnia. Should have known, with a handle like "Black Adder", it
had to be offbeat humor.

Roger Kumar wrote:

>  Then another cop started babbling how he was around in the sixties', and
 how they had >free concerts at Haight, and how we should get some
corporate  sponsorship, and how there >was never going to be a Rave Party
without  E.

How can we get it through these people's heads that we don't need or desire
"CORPORATE
sponsorship". This could only bring upon a distortion of what underground
free events have
always epitomized. That if somehow, we took advertiser's money, all would
be licit. As for his
drug reference, I don't believe that E is required to have a good time. The
experience is
what you put into it, not what you ingest. I haven't any fantasies about a
drug free rave 
scene, but I'm tired of people thinking that raves exist for the purpose of
using drugs. Most 
are there to dance and meet people. I think the music and the positive
energy stand on their
own as a creative entity. And we have all seen the effects commercialism
has had on creative 
expression; and it isn't often honorable. 

Be kind to those around you,
                                           Jason

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jun 25 11:04:21 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id LAA04038; Tue, 25 Jun 1996 11:04:21 -0700

Received: from saucer.cc.umr.edu (saucer.cc.umr.edu [131.151.1.58]) via ESMTP by hermes.cc.umr.edu (8.7.5/R.4.16) id NAA29047; Tue, 25 Jun 1996 13:04:04 -0500 (CDT)

Subject: re: Orbital/Undies
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 25 Jun 1996 13:04:03 -0500 (CDT)
From: "roger kumar" <rkumar@umr.edu>
X-Www-Page: http://www.umr.edu/~rkumar/
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Last night I headed into sf with justin and sami, all prepared to see
Orbital and Underworld with the tickets I won from the cool people at
KALX. We arrived at the fillmore, picked up the tickets and some free
apples, and headed for the dancefloor. A DJ who i didn't recognize was
spinning and a handful of people were dancing, but this being my first
big party in a long long time, i was not concentrating on his set at all.
After adjusting to the space, we met up with some other sfravers..
brandon, christy?, jess, kaySee, nancy.. i'm really bad with names. we 
headed back into the dance area as orbital was preparing to go on. I 
thought Orbital were pretty great untiul I saw them live. Now I
consider them demi-gods. Last night they delivered an absolutely perfect 
set, with the same style of breaks and melodies that that I fell in love 
with several years ago. Orbital still influences a lot of the stuff we 
write and play, and seeing them live with cool projectors and decent 
intelligent lighting was a total trip. I was entirely taken by this band, 
and probably at times forgot to dance, which was ok, because every once 
in a while the club gods would draw near and dance very aggresively and 
break me out of my little trance. Sometimes they would leave to go get a 
drink, but they would make sure to leave their girlfriends behind. "hey, 
see that guy chillin to Orbital? go dance really really close to him". 
but even that was ok, because i was near several list people, who were 
very kind. After Orbital and their encore, justin and i went upstairs, 
got a coffee, and listened to me live ambient performance already in 
progress. of course, like so many other parties, you could hear the bass 
of the main room, but it was ok, i'm used to that now. We made it back 
down right in time for underworld's set and found the other net people 
again. underworld began with intense beats, and everyone was totally 
going wild. but there were way too many people too close to me, and the 
sound was too loud (wasn't smart enough to bring earplugs and they 
weren't smart enough to turn it down a notch, my ears _still_ hurt). i 
couldn't get into their set right away, i suppose i was still in love 
with orbital. someone forgot to hit the 'data screen' button on the sony 
vtr. but after about an hour-and-a-half(?) people started to drift away 
and i had more room and got sucked in to the set and danced and danced 
until after the encore and i was very tired and had to work and headed 
back to berkeley with justin. 

i've been going to one-two parties a day lately, and am totally in love 
with the bay area again. i wish i never had to leave. thanks to all the 
people i've met, those on the list, those who throw parties on the beach, 
those who let me spin records at their parties on the beach, those 
incredible sunsets, and those whose names i always forget. now i'm ready 
for work, and maybe (hopefully) i will see you all the crash worship 
show tonight. 

-- 
pJou_|        			 pgp encrypted fone and mail accepted
    _l				 rkumar@lbl.gov        rkumar@umr.edu

> chicken? yucky. i have never eaten meat, and never will.

> "Eat People, Not Animals"
>-- End of excerpt from Wumpus 99

And I was so surprised to see that McDonald's now carries the figures from
the movie "Babe" with its happymeals. Now "Babe" is essentially trying to
tell us that pigs are cute and perhaps we shouldn't kill them like flies.
I guess McDonalds thought, well they didn't have any cows in the movie
so nobody will probably get make the connection that we are selling
dead cows with a cute little piggy. Even more amazing is that apparently
the people who made the movie (and made sure that all pigs involved live
happily ever after) gave them the rights to use the pictures main characters
as advertisement material...

A bewildered,

Frying Dutchman (not even a vegetarian)

P.S. And don't get me started on the ads by Tylenol where people, one day
after knee surgery, are back in the gym, taking pain killers in order to
silence there apparently protesting body. Or buy huge sausages and peppers
and take some mylanta, or whatever, in advance since they already know
that their stomach will upset. Weird...

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jun 25 12:56:10 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id MAA17045; Tue, 25 Jun 1996 12:56:10 -0700
Received: from value.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id MAA17009; Tue, 25 Jun 1996 12:55:54 -0700
Received: (from scarab@localhost) by value.net (8.6.12/8.6.9) id MAA19899; Tue, 25 Jun 1996 12:55:46 -0700
Date: Tue, 25 Jun 1996 12:55:45 -0700 (PDT)
From: KaySEE <scarab@value.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Anarchy in the U.S.A
Message-ID: <Pine.BSD/.3.91.960625122638.13104F-100000@value.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

You wake up, it's Monday morning and you are really bummed that reality 
has to set in again.  Damn, you live for the weekends.  Oh well, you make 
the daily trek to your lab.  Hmm... Some exciting stuff, you might get to 
mentor a high school student.  Hmm...cool.  Regular day but, there's 
something different in the air.

The afternoon comes, your friends are calling you at work to find a place 
to meet you at the show.  You sense the anticipation, the excitement, hmm...
You go to your 7 pm meeting, leave early, fight over the car with your 
sister, eat bad food because you can't cook.  Hmm...coffee sounds good 
about now.  You leave the apartment, get gas, think about how dangerous 
your car is getting because you are too lazy to get it fixed.  (Besides, 
you know you should be able to do it yourself!)  Then you are crossing 
the Bay Bridge and watching an 8:30 sunset.  Cool, three sunsets in three 
days; can't beat that.

You look for parking on Geary, oops, missed the turn off.  You find 
parking, just in time to meet your friends at 9 pm at the Fillmore.  Yay, 
said friends are in place.  Plus, added bonus, you meet two new sfravers
(hi Roger and Justin).  Cool dj is spinnning.  Everyone groups up and you 
go to the dance floor to find the right space.  Space is very important 
to you, you need dancing room and a place to hang out!  Said space is 
found.  Orbital comes on.  Wow, ohmigod, this is awesome.  The dance 
floor is packed.  People are sweaty, people are groovin', funky guys are 
on stage with lights on their heads that look like eyes.  The dance floor 
is packed, hot, slick with sweat.

The lights are amazing.  Circular beams of blue and white light look like 
Close Encounters of the Third Kind.  Then the spot lights cease and 
yellow lights are aimed at a giant disco ball that transforms into a 
psychedelic sun.

You're with your best fiends, new friends, boyfriend, and all of them are 
smiling.  What more could you ask for?  Then, Orbital is finished.  The 
two smiling, groovin' guys on stage who entrance the crowd say farewell.  
The floor clears, black lights come on.  A dj spins trance.  You love the 
fact that the frequency has hit your bpm level and you now have room to 
really groove.  You leave the dance floor for 2.2 seconds to grab a 
little bit of water and continue groovin'

Then, the crowd returns to see three of the coolest guys ever.  
Underworld arrives and knocks your socks off.  You can't stop dancing.  
The band is so into it that they are bouncing around the stage.  You are 
going crazy.  The peace pipe is passed around to everyone within a 20 
foot radius.  God, people are so beautiful, you think.  Your body is 
sufficiently groovin' to some fast bpm, your mind is caught in the music, 
THEN, the *wicked* smile comes.  Why, do you ask, is it wicked?   Well, 
you have now reached this stage where a mere smile won't do, it is time 
to dawn the *wicked* grin; the epitome of brilliance, of bliss, of harmony, 
of life.  Besides, you feel so naughty for having such a wicked time, 
that the wicked smile takes on a life of it's own. 

The lights are crazy, best light show you've ever seen.  The crowd is 
amazing; this is the friendliest, most down-to-earth concert you've ever 
been to.  You don't want this to ever stop, your friends are in 
agreement.  You're holding hands, hugging, where am I again?  Underworld 
doesn't want to stop either, they are having what seems to be the time of 
their life.  They are true professionals at this and know how to work the 
crowd.  Hmm, they've done this before.  You ponder the thought that the 
U.S. invents some music, the U.K. perfects it, and then we finally get 
the idea.  Hmm, happened to rock, punk rock, and now this!!

Underworld stops, but aren't difficult to coax back on for an encore.  
They look so happy it's catching.  You are dancing, knowing these are the 
fleeting moments, when someone grabs your hand.  All of a sudden you are 
a part of a huge circle that has formed in the middle of the dance 
floor.  Everyone is smiling, a few wicked grins are afloat, and then the 
climax comes.  Hugs envelope the dance floor.  It is over.  You say 
goodbye.  You drive home.

On the way, you ask yourself,  "THIS was Monday?"  

You wake up Tuesday, a bit tired, but in a sheer state of bliss.  Then, 
you remember you're going to Crash Worship on Tuesday.  What's going on 
here, it is only the *beginning* of this week.  You're scared to see the 
end of the week!!!  Insane, absolutely insane.

--KaySEE


              ****Shit, goddamn, get off your ass and jam****

I won't repeat the reviews of the show (it was great), but I did
want to mention that the Fillmore is a *great* venue.  The sound
was good (the bass *hit* rather than swelled -- I hate it when
it just swells at you).

There was *free* SELF-SERVE water.  Meaning, a pitcher which the
bartenders would frequently refill, and little paper cups.

And there was a tub of fresh *free* APPLES, for crying out loud.

I ate one and it was good.

	Sami

        when i was a kid, I lived on a farm. We had 2 sheep (named Laverne &
Shirley - it was the 70's)that had lotsa offspring and lotsa chickens. I
loved 'em. Charlottes web was one of my favorite books. But when it was
dinnertime, the lamb and chicken sure tasted good. 
        What I'm saying is: as a little kid, If you are only a few years
old, the concept of death is not really understood yet. Mcdonalds knows
that, and the can market Babe with the happy meal which has all of babe's
dead friends in it. (speak -o- the devil- the commercial for Icky-D's just
aired on the TV.)
        I am a vegetarian, however not a vegetarian because of what is
morally right (one could say that a plant has as much right and need for
life as an animal due to its alkaloids and other defense systems that it
develops to stay alive). I'm a vegetarian because of the unsanitary way the
meat is raised, not to mention a family histor of colon cancer. And seeing
McDonalds selling burgers for $0.39 makes you wonder.  BUT - It would be
nice if parents would let their kids know that what McDonalds is doing is
not right.

Yep,

The Junglish songs are from the new album. I'm not familiar with the names
of them yet...maybe tomorrow. The new stuff is darker, moodier and more
"cinematic" in general.
I particulary like the tune on it that sounds like it's inspired by Ennio
Morricone.
At one stage i thought they sounded really industrial, especially when they
played "Satan" .
I was reminded of the Trocadero  where I went to see the Chemical brothers
on Friday, and there's no competition;  last nights shows at the Fillmore
won, no contest
And of course, "Halcyon and on and on..." was a beautiful finish.


Ciaran

Hello all you happy campers!  Fourth of July weekend July 5th-7th there will
be a Light Gathering in the woods.  The drive is 2 1/2 hrs away.  (Just north
of Placerville off of Hwy. 50)   Activities include -  hiking, swimming in
the nearby lake, dancing, mountain biking, games, relaxing, and getting in
touch with mother earth.  There will be breakfast served on Saturday and
Sunday morning and a common cooking area. The area is remote and beautiful.  

The line-up includes - John Carel, Minor Minor, Monty, James Dee, Ethan,
Erika, Sean Murray, Alex, Joe Rice, and Andrew.  Ambient Sounds with
Consciousness Lab Collective, Rob, and Claire. Friday night groove out  and
Saturday night groove out harder with the daytime reserved mostly for rest
and play. Please call 415.536.9453 for ticket info. $15 If you would like to
offer a ride to this event or need a ride please e-mail Claire at
Clarityi@aol.com and title the subject   "Light Ride" or "need Light Ride".
 Thank You.  Enjoy Summer while it's here!   
                                                                       Feel
It - Love
                                                                   -Gateway

ANNOUNCEMENT:

first planning meeting of the GGMLSR
(golden gate malt liquor soccer rave)

is Tonight at the "bayside" bar.  For those
of you familiar with lasers - this IS the bar
that projects there name with a blue laser onto the sidewalk
out on the street.  They also have Very Large murals of
muscular women playing volleyball.

I'm interested in getting those giant inflatible
cartoon characters they use in parades.  Any suggestions?
One could feasibly modify them to carry psychedelic
lighting on board.

Just bagged PE for a second stage live performance
and picked up Shmidt STick skateboards as another
sponsor.

Also note - $2 spaghetti dinner tent.

Everyone going to Crash Worship should bring
sliced oranges.  Please throw them at the band
if they play an encore.

Dave

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Bliss 99 <erase99@sirius.com>
Subject: orbital/underworld
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

well.. went to the show last night with jess, kristi (not on the list),
kirsten, john (kirsten's bfriend), nancy, and two of nancy's friends who's
names i have forgotten. :(
met up with rog and justin, who recognized my glowsticks. i was the only one
there with them! i think i saw a head way above the crowd that i assumed was
todd, but i didn't make it over to say hi.. and i got briefly introduced to
umm.. [name forgotten already] the man with the burger king hat - without
the burger king hat. met up with my pal forrest, and john drefahl (who is
new to the list).

the only negative thing: i offered this big dude my glowsticks to play with,
and he ripped the strings off and chucked one of the glowsticks somewhere
into the crowd! :( a real bummer because after he did that i realized that i
wanted to give them to karl (of underworld) on stage, cause he was going
crazy and looked like he would have loved them. (a little anecdote here: my
friend went to feile in ireland last summer and saw underworld there. he
threw his hat up on stage and karl picked it up and wore it for the whole
performance. =) 

anyway.. spacetime continuum didn't play live - jonah just spun. orbital
came on and played a great set, certainly better than the last time i heard
them in toronto. they stopped between songs, which they hadn't done the last
time. that kind of dissapointed me. but they made up for it with some huge
tunes. i haven't heard the whole album yet, because i bought it on vinyl,
with the assumption that i would have a record player soon - but don't yet.
:p   anyway.. the one song that starts of with the father talking to the son
and saying "and next time you see your mother, say hello to SATAN SATAN
SATAN SATAN... etc..   was IMMENSE! orbital has done a great job with their
video - the video for that song was especially sick. they finished off the
set beautifully - i had really wanted them to play Belfast, but i guess it's
good they didn't because i would have died and missed...

Underworld! Now, my friend came back from europe and said underworld was the
best live act he had ever seen. now i can happily concur. they are simply
amazing. absolutely beautiful mixing and improvisation - but i of course
expected that from the band that once played a 13 hour set. when they
started off i was a little dissapointed in their sound. it didn't seem very
interesting to me. of course, when i realized i should take out my earplugs
i heard what they were really doing. wow! stupid earplugs took out _all_ the
high end. i couldn't hear half the music! anyway, all i can say is wow. wow.
wow. wow. if orbital are demi-gods, then underworld are gods. karl just went
nuts on stage. so much fun. they played born slippy! =)  at the end of born
slippy karl said thanks, this was their last day in america, this was the
first time they had ever been to america and we've had a fucking great time,
etc.. etc.., and said that this was their last song. they left the stage,
but the crowd was having none of that. underworld charged back on stage and
started up what sounded like it was going to be Cowgirl, but they mixed into
Rez (absolutely awesome), back into Cowgirl, and back to Rez to finish the
set. wow.

kristi and kirsten were so happy that i talked them into coming to the show.
they are now die-hard underworld converts.. =)  as i'm sure _anyone_ who
caught their set is now.
and to anyone who left after orbital: i wish i'd met you so i could have
talked you into staying for underworld. work or no work, it was the
experience of a lifetime.

brendan

>first planning meeting of the GGMLSR

isn't malt liquor very bad for you?

and did you know that for my 19 years in canada - i never once saw anyone
drink malt liquor. i only saw one brand of it in the liquor store, and i
swear the same bottle has been there for years.
when i first moved here, someone told me they had drank (drunk, drinken?
what _is_ the correct word, anyways??) a 40 the night before. i was suitably
impressed, because back home we always referred to a 40 as a 40oz bottle of
hard liquor - not malt liquor. i thought this guy was a serious bad-ass
hardcore drinker. it took me a little while to realize he had been talking
about malt liquor instead. =)

Plus the pink limited vinyl of Rez with Why Why Why on the B side and Mmmm
Skyscraper I Love You, one of their first techno singles. And of course
Underneath the Radar, an MTV smash in what, 1987? And then "Doot Doot" by
Freur, an earlier incarnation. But that's more than you probably want to
know.

I think the new single is Pearls Girl or Juanita.

I didn't stick around for much or Underworld. Too clubby in comparison to
Orbital, but it sounds like I missed out. Orbital were great as usual, and
the tracks from In Sides didn't sound bad at all.

Joe

> your friend but until they experience what you love, they'll try to push you
> to what they love. That's how it is.

Interesting!
So he should make his roommate experience what he likes, so that
his friends stops pushing him to experience what he likes...

> Someone likes what they do and they try
> to get others to join in on "their" game.

But that's exactly what you would like the original poster to do, take
his room mate to a rave and let him see "the light".

>        Did that help????

Not really I guess. My $0.02, if he's curious he'll come by himself,
otherwise, let him remain in his little universe of babes and bucks.
To each his/her own.

The Frying Dutchman

--

track on disc 2). I loved how they were just going crazy with the crowd at
the intense part of the song (had a kewlie organ sounds in it). *sigh*
orbital...very impressive!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jun 25 17:25:36 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id RAA15029; Tue, 25 Jun 1996 17:25:36 -0700
Received: from aoaioxxysz.organic.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id RAA14993; Tue, 25 Jun 1996 17:25:26 -0700
Received: from aoaioxxysz.organic.com (localhost [127.0.0.1]) by aoaioxxysz.organic.com (8.7.5/8.6.12) with ESMTP id RAA11666; Tue, 25 Jun 1996 17:26:36 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <199606260026.RAA11666@aoaioxxysz.organic.com>
To: Intellectually Dismissive Muzak <idm@hyperreal.com>
cc: San Francisco Raves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>, johnsin@cyborganic.net
Subject: Keep the Crossover
Date: Tue, 25 Jun 1996 17:26:36 -0700
From: ozymandias G desiderata <ogd@organic.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I just wanted to relate some brief (you can start laughing now)
impressions of my experience at the Orbital / Underworld show in San
Francisco last night, with maybe a brief jog into discussing last
Friday's Chemical Brothers show.

I had a great time. I mean, a _really_ great time. I haven't danced this
hard since last October's great Friends and Family party. I was a fish on
a line all night long (aka: hooked), and was only briefly able to stop
dancing.  Everything about the show kept me moving, from the tight (if
overly treble-heavy) sound, the great lighting and video, and the
MUSIC. My goodness, the music.

So, specifics. I got to the show at around 9:00. Either Jonah Sharpe
didn't play live or he was the gent with the short-cropped hair dropping
the hard funked Detroit jams. I have to give that guy props. He may
always be riding the current trend (and make no mistake - the Detroit
sound is _very_ trendy amongst the SF techno elite right now. Big ups to
Jon Santos and Joe Rice for being two of the biggest perpetrators behind
this fashion conspiracy), but he does it with style and (dare I say it)
panache. I approved.

The DJ that followed him, though, completely knocked my shit right
out. From step one he started dropping the cold, dark techno jams that
give me body rushes and make me jerk spasmodically. Cool, precise mixes
of tons of material on Reload records (the choice of discerning darkcore
beat junkies everywhere), and a few notable surprises (of which I will
write more anon). He was exceptional (in my incredibly arrogant opinion
-- I imagine that many of my compatriots at the show were less than
thrilled. TOO BAD. I was happier than a pig in slop ;). I didn't know
they let DJs like that play in SF. Does anybody have any clue who he was?

Somewhere along there the DJ winked out and Orbital clambered up to take
the stage. As has been mentioned, one of the two Ps was wearing a laser
pointer strapped to his flashlight glasses. He did funny things with it
all night, but really, who gives a shit?

Orbital were all about THE MUSIC. The lights were great, the video was
just as good as I was led to expect, but oh dear, I got my ass rocked by
the sounds pounding their way away from the speakers. I mean, they
_started_ with my current favorite Orbital song ("Out There Somewhere")
and proceeded to methodically work their way through the high points of
their already very high-point-laden catalog. The reworks of "Choice" and
"Satan" were particularly tasty, although I thought my ears were going to
jump off and make a run for the hills during the more trebly bits of
"Satan". Ouch. And, of course, they played "Halcyon" with the magic
little Belinda Carlisle bit, which probably would have affected me more
profoundly had I not already been expecting it. They finished with a
encore consisting of "Planet of the Shapes" and one of the songs off of
_Snivilization_ that I never bothered to learn the name of (me? dislike
_Snivilization_? Whatever made you think that?). I think that otherwise
their set was probably note-for-note the same as the set they did in LA.

I personally could have handled a tiny bit more reworking of Orbital's
material. I could hear what they were up to sometimes, but I think a lot
of the subtler knob-twiddling got lost, and it was sort of odd knowing
exactly where all of the breaks were going to occur. It was life-
affirming hearing the artists that made me decide that I wanted to be a
DJ play their music REAL LOUD through a big sound system, but I thought
one of the positive things about techno was that it encouraged
experimentation, right?

One thing that their video made much more explicit was that Orbital is
unusually political for techno artists. The video made explicit many
points about consumer culture, the power of symbols in our culture, and
our overweening blindness in the face of rampant environmental
destruction. I don't think I'm just pulling that out of my butt,
either. Some of it would have been difficult to misinterpret (like all of
the shots of guys with chainsaws cutting down trees, f'rinstance).

In any case, Orbital were exactly as stunning as I expected them to be,
and I could have gotten down on my knees and wept at the beauty of it
all, but I was too busy dancing and whooping and generally making an ass
of myself to be bothered with such maudlin sentiment (those of you who
were there -- I was the tall geeklike person with the pony-tail, packer
boots, and the bright cheery Public Image Limited T shirt who kept
screaming and had the amateur obstacle course set up next to his feet).

After Orbital left the stage, That DJ started up again, spinning more
incredible hard traxxy mean-spirited techno stuff, including (drum roll
please) the Prodigy remix of Front 242's "Religion". Keep the crossover
indeed. Both I and the recently-transplanted Midwesterner I was with were
well pleased and grinning like idiots at the surprisingly good music.
Don't get me wrong -- there are a lot of really good technohead DJs in
San Francisco, but I prefer a harder / more abstract sound than what most
people here spin, and it was good to hear some of my favorite tunes spun
loud.

After an interminable break while the road crew tore down Orbital's
incredibly huge stage setup and set up Underworld's marginally less
complex array of gear, Messrs Smith, Hyde, and Emerson took to the stage,
looking cheery and happy to be there. At this point, I was standing up on
the balcony, so was able to see what they were doing on stage, which was
basically live mixing of presequenced material. Don't forget that Darren
Emerson is a DJ first and foremost. I kinda wondered why they bothered
doing it that way, considering that it would have been just as easy to
sequence everything, but as they warmed to what they were doing they got
more fluid with the mixing and it all made sense.

They had a buttload of gear up on stage which I could be a faithful
little trainspotter for y'all and detail, but I won't. Suffice it to say
that they had the usual array of trendy techno gear, and my partner in
crime for the evening spent a good chunk of time torturing himself,
trying to decide if the little Roland box mounted vertically in one of
their rackmount cases was a 303 or a 606. He finally decided that it was
a 606 when he saw Karl Hyde tweaking the cymbals on it late in the
show. I'd much earlier decided that it really wasn't worth worrying
about. I will say for thems that's curious that they were making very
prominent (and obnoxious) use of a Nord Lead throughout the evening, and
made me decide that I need one of those, monophonic or not. They
certainly do make some jaggedly analogesque noises. I'll also say that it
was cool that the only use that I saw for the guitar that Mr. Hyde was
hauling around stage with him was to act as the frequency input for the
vocoder on his voice. I thought that was a neato change of pace.

They played a very long set of very dancy material, which suited me just
fine, because I was, in fact, there to dance. I personally thought that
the vocals were a perfect counterpoint for the music, but I think that we
established long ago that there are those that like Underworld's vocals
and those that find them superfluous and annoying. I'm one of the former.
High points for me included a great, extended version of "Pearls Girl"
and a nicely-done encore of "Cowgirl" and "Rez" played back to
back. Hearing "Rez" was a very intensely nostalgic moment for me. If
Underworld deserves to be remembered for only one thing, it's definitely
that song.

What struck me most about Underworld was the enthusiasm they brought to
their set. While Orbital were content to bob their heads energetically
and occasionally confer with each other, Underworld were positively goofy
with energy. All three of them were bobbling enthusiastically around the
stage, with Karl and Darren pausing periodically to hype up the crowd.
When Karl wasn't singing, he was running around the stage like Moby or
something. It was fun to watch. And, of course, getting to see the Tomato
video was cool, although it was pretty obvious that the videos were
intended to be set to different songs than the ones that were currently
playing (a disadvantage when a) your song has words and b) those words
are integrated pretty heavily into the video).

What was remarkable to me was that in the past two years I've gone from
being a die-hard anti-fan of Underworld's to thinking that they are
positively the bees' knees. The vocals used to _really_ get on my nerves
and the music didn't do much for me, but once again, as they finished off
Rez I was just about fit to cry (and just about to fall over, too -- I
haven't danced that hard in a LOOONG time).

I hadn't really thought about what an important show this was to me until
I was there last night, but both of these bands have played pivotal roles
in my musical development. If it hadn't been for Orbital, I never would
have decided to indulge my musical fanatacism and become a DJ, and if it
hadn't been for the amazing singles that Underworld put out a couple
years ago ("Spoon [Deep Mix]" anyone?), I'd be a much different sounding DJ
now. It was a good night.

As a brief side note, I did go to see Chemical Brothers last Friday
night, and they did in fact go straight for the throat. Those kids do
_not_ fuck around. Bombastic beats, dark atmospheres, and light-show
imagery rife with images of death, destruction, and repression.
Considering how often their music is played by jolly la-di-da handbag
club DJs, it was surprising how much their set made me think of a
different kind of club altogether. Most excellent, especially the new
material, which wasn't quite so {hip|trip|crip}-hop oriented. After they
got into a groove they even seemed to be having fun. I think I saw one of
them smile once or twice.

They also had another wonderful opening DJ (this time DJ Terminator, who
played excellent hardstep jungle with good humor, despite the fact that
he was in the lighting booth up near the ceiling, had no monitor, and
therefore had absolutely no idea what his mixing sounded like).
Unfortunately, the [expletive deleted] Trocadero had its usual quirks,
this time being a dishwater-dull crowd and some very irritating sound
system problems. I'm sorry, but every time I see the name "Blasthaus" on
a flyer, I _know_ the party's going to be full of the sort of irritating
faux-hipsters (which I guess could be shortened by the omission of the
"faux-") guaranteed to set my teeth on edge. Maybe I'm an opinionated,
easily-irritated codger, though. Maybe. 

I _was_ surprised at how friendly and cheerful the Trocadero doorfolk
were, I will admit. But now that I think about it, they've always been
nice to me, even when they've been firmly telling me (f'rinstance) that I
can't bring my pepper spray into the club. Maybe I just look close enough
to Goth to pass. Maybe I just relate well to shaven-head death-metal
headz. I shrug.

yrz,
ozymandias

onNow: sqpr - "tundra" / "dimotane co" (I have a feeling I like a
   completely different album than the rest of you, because tracks like
   these are peachy, but Mr. Jenkinson could drop his bass out the window
   and I'd still like the album just as much. In fact, the reason I like
   this album as much as I do has to do with its strong resemblance to
   works by *cough* Aphex Twin or *cough* *cough* Mu-Ziq more than any
   resemblance to the current crop of ambient jazz innovative listening
   progressive intelligent dolphin softstep jungle-meisters.)

       . . . the self-reflecting image of a narcotized mind . . .
ozymandias G desiderata      ogd@organic.com        Desperate, Deathless
(415)278-5674     http://www.organic.com/Staff/ogd/       ::AOAIOXXYSZ::

     Yes peoples, please let us be careful about labeling people. Ever 
     since I've been reading this list I've read complaints about 
     "gangsters", "vatos", and "esse's" invading YOUR scene(long before the 
     author of the JoCks post). What makes it YOUR scene? How can I make it 
     MY scene or better yet OUR scene? In reading this list and attending 
     parties I'm starting to feel that because I am latino and like to 
     sport a ball-cap, goatee and wear my pants sagging I'm invading YOUR 
     scene. The reason I like raving is because I can be myself and not 
     worry about people judging my appearance(so I've always thought). I 
     can go to clubs for that shit. I've done the club scene and I hate it. 
     Who's to say that "the scene" belongs to a certain group or style of 
     people? I've met jerks of all colors and races at parties as well as 
     really great people. You preach love and unity yet you sit here and 
     complain of others' invading and ruining your scene. On top of that it 
     seems that it's always the "vato's" and "esse's" that are the bad 
     guys. That's B*llshit!
        I've gone to parties and sat on the wall for the whole night, or 
     danced all night, I've gone sober, and I've E'd my ass off. People 
     like to party in different ways. I admit that when I first started 
     raving one of the main reasons was because it was a place to get high 
     and hang out for the night. But I have since realized that there is a 
     lot more to it than that. It may take some longer than others to 
     realize the true benefits of raving. Some may never realize. Give 
     people a chance. Raving has definately changed my outlook on things 
     but not my wardrobe. If this is how you like to judge people then I 
     don't want to be part of YOUR scene. I'd rather chill with my 
     "gangster" friends. Kno' wha' I'm sayin'? 
        I went to Harmony last month and kept getting these looks like I 
     didn't belong there. Just how so many of you talk in this list I was 
     looked at like I was invading there party. Like I belonged at a 
     CoolWorld party or something(fuck that). If you don't like the people 
     who show up at the parties you go to throw a private fucking party. 
     Otherwise do what I do just smile and keep walking. This isn't 
     directed to anyone in particular. Just wanted to voice an opinion from 
     another perspective. I welcome any and all comments\opinions. Later 
     y'all!
     
     Sorry so long, just needed to vent and make a point to all the 
     hypocrits out there.
     
            -Renzo-

From: TRISTAN BERNARD BLAUG <sandoz@sfsu.edu>
X-Sender: sandoz@pluto
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: The Orbital show.
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960625185855.25226A-100000@pluto>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

That has to have been one of the worst shows I have ever been to.  
Despite the fact that Orbital played an amfuckngmazing set everything 
else sucked.
Firstly, the sound was so bad that at times not only the (deep) bass but 
some of the mid and treble was so distorted that it bbelittled the power 
of the music.  The reason?  Techno music is, like vynal, sythetic sounds 
created from a pre-programmed memory which  means that they 
were created at a different frequency then if they had been composed by 
live electronic instrument (such as a guitar).  Therefore, anytime you 
play sythicated music through a live, rather then rave, speaker system 
it is going to sound like shit no matter how good the bands equipment is 
(and Orbital's equipment was the bollocks; did anyone check that out?) 
or the venues PA is.  Last time I saw Orbital here it was a few years 
back at that Galleria show downtown and THAT was a show.  The soud there 
was amazing because it done up for a rave and not for a band.  And so 
the question still remains: how could the Fillmore, or Orbital for 
that matter, no know this?  The least thing that the they vould have 
done was to have scraped the house system and have got the Whicked 
system in instead which is a) much louder and (most importantly) deeper 
and b)  it is operated by people that really understand techno music and how 
to make it sound good; the sound guy for the house did not have a clue.
  Secomdly, the visuals, which were mind blowing, were completely waisted 
owing to the fact that they were being projected onto three little 
screens that were being oscured by lighting racks.  Owing to the lack of 
lyrics in Orbitals music (although the vocal samples they use are 
inspired genius) the only other way they have of getting there messgae 
across is through there vissuals.  At the Galleria show the screens, 
which were much bigger, where stationed in front of tre stage and this 
worked far better as one felt that they were part of the visuals and that 
they were directly talking to you are your life.  This deffinatly did not 
happen (to me) at the Fillmore show.
The only thing that saved the show was the lighting which was 
mindblowing.
There were also way to many people there and the tempreture was so 
hot that I almost passed out a few times because of it.  Now I know that 
owing to my British heritage I am a lightweight when it comes to heat I 
looked around the venue and noticed that I was not the only punter who 
was suffering from this problem.  I really wanted to stay for all of 
Underworld but the heat was making me fall asleep so I had to leave.  
What I want to know is bearing in mind that the Fillmore made bank and 
knew that they were going to the least thing they could have done was got 
in a few of those large industrial fans to cool the place down.  But oh 
yeah I forgot, there're only interested in our money so what the fuck do 
they care?
There was also no vibe from the crowd what-so ever.  They all looked 
liked fresh young white thing's from the territories who did not look 
like they could blow there nose let alone understand the complexties and 
conceptulization of Orbitals music.  Remember: Orbital are not some 
kiddie arese rave band but intelligent adults making intelligent music 
for intelligent music.  They are educating as well entertaining there 
audiance; it''s just a shame that the vast majority (although not all) of 
there audiance in the US (going on te crowd last night) simply do nat 
have a clue.
And lastly: fuck Bill Graham presents and, especially, fuck BASS who 
force great bands to play in totally unsuited venues.  What I want to 
know is why can't we organize an Orbital show?  We can get better venues 
with bettewr sound equipment and have a better show.  Thats what the 
Galleria show was and it was a 1000% better because of it.
Also, until last night, I had never even heard of Underworld.  While they 
did not exactly suck they Are mere minions compared to Orbital so why the 
fuck did they go on last?  I knew people there wjho had just come to see 
Orbital and arrived late because they were on at 9.30! (a ridiculasly 
early hour' 4.00 a.m would have been much better.

Orbital are one of my favourite bands and I was sad to see that there 
genius was being wasisted at a bad venue with a majoritivly weak crowd.  
Please, cant we do better next time?  What about a whole weekend live 
techno fest with Orbital, The Orb, System 7, Higher Intelligence Agency 
and, especially Richard.H Kirk (Caberet Voltaire, Sandoz, electronic 
Eye,) who still kicks arse over everybody including Orbital.  Ah well, 
better luck next time I guess.

Tristan.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: johnsin@xanadu.cyborganic.net (John Drefahl)
Subject: Orbital/underworld/massivereview
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, I went, I saw, and no this isn't going to say, I kicked ass.

I was undoubtly impressed by Orbital and Underworld.  I have been to many a
live performances in my day.  Most are basically just some joe hitting the
DAT play button, and them all jumping around doing nothing real exciting.

But this was a bit different.

I didn't see much of Orbital up front (lack of glasses because I was
dancing like nuts) so I couldn't really go and check the gear out.  I dug
the influence of Breakbeat in both acts.. True to the english tradition,
you felt the essence of the 'ardcore in many of the selctions..  I nice
slow break with a harpsichord breakdown was nothing less but extraordinary
originality.. Hell, oribital knew what to do, they took a trend and made
something completely new and exciting from something totally over used, and
old.

Now Underworld was great.  I have never seen three people come on the stage
pretty nervous, and by the end figuring out that they had the crowd under
their control.. Major respect goes out to them for doing a fantastic live
performance.. This was as live as you could get with that much equipement..
The fact that there appeared to be no DAT shit being pulled totally
impressed me..

The vibe was like no other I have experienced.. People were there and
having fun, and totally into it.. I was a bit suprised and happy to be
apart of this first time rave sensation of SF.  cough: and the waify girl
with the red hair and sunglasses.. you have some wicked eyebrows..nice one!

The midwest is another world, with another feeling, but the ravers here do
understand something that newyork has refused to get... The music is what
it is all about, keep it that way, and you got great days to come..

Later, and have a bloody fucking good day.
Johnsin

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Jun 25 22:03:52 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id WAA08609; Tue, 25 Jun 1996 22:03:52 -0700
Received: from itsa.ucsf.EDU by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id WAA08604; Tue, 25 Jun 1996 22:03:49 -0700
Received: from localhost (jfogler@localhost) by itsa.ucsf.EDU (8.6.8/GSC4.24) with SMTP
	id WAA137213 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 25 Jun 1996 22:03:53 -0700
Date: Tue, 25 Jun 1996 22:03:53 -0700 (PDT)
From: jess <jfogler@itsa.ucsf.EDU>
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Orbital/Underimpressed
Message-ID: <Pine.A32.3.93.960625215121.93309A-100000@itsa.ucsf.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Excuse me but did someone slip happy pills into everyones water last night
and somehow I missed the dose???

I thought the Orbital/Underworld show was straight ahead mediocre:
Orbital played a set that was largely verbatim off their new CD - I
mean note for note, no mixing, no playing around, no nothing - they
seemed to be jumping around a lot in order to hide the fact that they had
nothing to do on stage except press play occasionally.  The sound system
sucked big time - really muddy and way too loud.  


Underworld had a lot more energy and played a pretty danceable set.  It
was pretty fun to see them bopping around on the stage but this was _far_
from the most impressive live show I've ever seen. I amused myself in the
back trying to pick up some new dance moves by copying people in front
of me without being noticed.

Perhaps the evening was doomed the moment my bag was searched outside and
my powerbar confiscated (the scandal!)...

Plan for the week:  get lots of rest and get ready for a weekend which I
hope will restore my faith in techno...

		Ranting and Raving

		    ** jess **

On Tue, 25 Jun 1996, TRISTAN BERNARD BLAUG wrote:

> Firstly, the sound was so bad that at times not only the (deep) bass but 
> some of the mid and treble was so distorted that it bbelittled the power 
> of the music.  The reason?  Techno music is, like vynal, sythetic sounds 
> created from a pre-programmed memory which  means that they 
> were created at a different frequency then if they had been composed by 
> live electronic instrument (such as a guitar).  Therefore, anytime you 
> play sythicated music through a live, rather then rave, speaker system 
> it is going to sound like shit no matter how good the bands equipment is 
> (and Orbital's equipment was the bollocks; did anyone check that out?) 
> or the venues PA is.  Last time I saw Orbital here it was a few years 
> back at that Galleria show downtown and THAT was a show.  The soud there 
> was amazing because it done up for a rave and not for a band.  And so 
> the question still remains: how could the Fillmore, or Orbital for 
> that matter, no know this?  The least thing that the they vould have 
> done was to have scraped the house system and have got the Whicked 
> system in instead which is a) much louder and (most importantly) deeper 
> and b)  it is operated by people that really understand techno music and how 
> to make it sound good; the sound guy for the house did not have a clue.

I really didnt think the sound was as bad as you make it out to be, 
although it would have been nice to have some more subs, the sound at the 
SoCal show was phenomenal.

>   Secomdly, the visuals, which were mind blowing, were completely waisted 
> owing to the fact that they were being projected onto three little 
> screens that were being oscured by lighting racks.  Owing to the lack of 
> lyrics in Orbitals music (although the vocal samples they use are 
> inspired genius) the only other way they have of getting there messgae 
> across is through there vissuals.  At the Galleria show the screens, 
> which were much bigger, where stationed in front of tre stage and this 
> worked far better as one felt that they were part of the visuals and that 
> they were directly talking to you are your life.  This deffinatly did not 
> happen (to me) at the Fillmore show.

The visuals rocked.  I don't see how you thought they were that obscured, 
they really werent behind those lights that much.

> The only thing that saved the show was the lighting which was 
> mindblowing.
> There were also way to many people there and the tempreture was so 
> hot that I almost passed out a few times because of it.  Now I know that 
> owing to my British heritage I am a lightweight when it comes to heat I 
> looked around the venue and noticed that I was not the only punter who 
> was suffering from this problem.  I really wanted to stay for all of 
> Underworld but the heat was making me fall asleep so I had to leave.  
> What I want to know is bearing in mind that the Fillmore made bank and 
> knew that they were going to the least thing they could have done was got 
> in a few of those large industrial fans to cool the place down.  But oh 
> yeah I forgot, there're only interested in our money so what the fuck do 
> they care?

Again, it really wasnt that hot.  Have you ever been to some of the 
smaller parties in SF, say some of the past Komotion parties?  Now that's 
hot.  I actually thought the temperature was rather pleasnat the entire 
night.

> There was also no vibe from the crowd what-so ever.  They all looked 
> liked fresh young white thing's from the territories who did not look 
> like they could blow there nose let alone understand the complexties and 
> conceptulization of Orbitals music.  Remember: Orbital are not some 
> kiddie arese rave band but intelligent adults making intelligent music 
> for intelligent music.  They are educating as well entertaining there 
> audiance; it''s just a shame that the vast majority (although not all) of 
> there audiance in the US (going on te crowd last night) simply do nat 
> have a clue.

As much as you may not have thought there was a vibe I guess you should 
be glad that you did not go to the socal show.  SF was a thousand times 
more vibey.  I ran into smiling people all night long!  I talked with one 
of the Hartnoll Brothers from Orbital and he loved the crowd.  Maybe you 
were in a bad part of the dance floor?!

> And lastly: fuck Bill Graham presents and, especially, fuck BASS who 
> force great bands to play in totally unsuited venues.  What I want to 
> know is why can't we organize an Orbital show?  We can get better venues 
> with bettewr sound equipment and have a better show.  Thats what the 
> Galleria show was and it was a 1000% better because of it.
> Also, until last night, I had never even heard of Underworld.  While they 
> did not exactly suck they Are mere minions compared to Orbital so why the 
> fuck did they go on last?  I knew people there wjho had just come to see 
> Orbital and arrived late because they were on at 9.30! (a ridiculasly 
> early hour' 4.00 a.m would have been much better.

The show wasnt Bill Graham, trust me your ticket would have said bgp on 
it if it were.  I thought the venue was very appropriate.  Events in the 
Galleria arent really that feasible anymore as I understand it, when was 
the last event there?  Find some of the promoters in town a place to do 
it and they probably would!  Really  what space are out there these 
days?  I disagree about Orbital coming on first, I think it worked out 
great and not everyone came to see Orbital, I for one came to see 
Underworld! who rocked my ass!

> Orbital are one of my favourite bands and I was sad to see that there 
> genius was being wasisted at a bad venue with a majoritivly weak crowd.

From: David Lowe <dlowe@best.com>

Subject: Hi everyone!

  Hope this is the friendly kind of mailing list where you just introduce
yourself, 'cause that's what I'm about to do!
  I'm new to San Francisco, only been here a couple of months and still
not really settled in.  I've yet to go to a rave here, for lack of
funds/time and the overwhelming and undigestable volume of available
information.  I've been raving for around 3 years, which is a long time
where I come from - Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.
  Ottawa has a small scene (no rave has yet drawn a crowd of over 1000,
and most don't break 300), which was great for me.  It was really like a
family - there were always dozens of familiar faces to be seen at every
party.  Even though the scene is small, there is a proportionally large
'core' group who can be found at most any of the raves.
  Anyway, I'll probably start going to raves around here on a regular
basis fairly soon, but I wanted to know if anyone can help me to find
events where I'll feel more like a part of a family than part of a throng.
I'd love to go to an outdoor party - never have, Ottawa has horrible
weather for it.  And I've seen some insane prices out here too, which I'd
rather not have to pay (the music and the vibe are important to me, not
the number of people or the DJs' reputations)... 
  And also, I'd really like to meet people!  I moved down here on a whim,
basically, with no friends or anything.  I'd love to meet some of my
friendly neighborhood ravers :)
  Take care all...

: : J. David Lowe ::: dlowe@best.com ::: ai334@freenet.carleton.ca : :

::: un*x, C, Common Lisp, HTML, network, hardware & reality hacker :::

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id AAA21118; Wed, 26 Jun 1996 00:36:40 -0700

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Precedence: bulk

[ to sfraves list ]
( Please excuse any errors in my writing - I'm under the influence of
champagne gifted to us from my mother-in-law - a few glasses in honor
of a personal milestone achieved! )
 
 Recently , Austin asked about the Sunday evening weekly called Mantra -
 
> What's this Mantra.  Is this a weekly on Sundays?  Hmmmm can I get more
> info on this from anyone. I'd like to check it....if the trancedance is
> nice...

 The trancedance is AMAZING! 

 I went to my first MANTRA event this Sunday. It's scheduled to go from 
10PM to 3PM, but they were about 1/2hr late opening this time. While the
event is held in the Cat's Grill (?) , the actual entrance is located
in an alley of Clemetina St. - alley entrance is off of 8th St. between
Howard and Folsom. Admission was $5, ids checked to verify if you're 18
or older. Also, the flyer I have says "NO ADMITTANCE AFTER 2AM". 

 The first DJ up was Dutch ( now, after close-cropping his head , going
by the DJ handle Starbuck ). He was GREAT! I was happily bopping away
to his wonderful trance selections for almost his whole set! Not just
monorythmic 4/4 stuff , but some wicked syncopated stuff too! I will
definetly try to attend any future events he might be spinning at.

 After Dutch was what I think was a two-person band called CIEBA. One of
them is a guy who works at Frequency 8 , the other a bald white male who
I don't know. ( Anybody in SFRaves land know what individual names these
guys go by ? ). Great stuff too! Very interesting to watch as well , if
you're curious of how live techno would work. They played synths and
rhythm boxes ( at least a Roland keyboard and a Novation BassStation ),
or spun records , or a mix of records and live music.  

 Going by the flyer, I guess the guy in spinning ambient and trip-hop 
and etc. for the area in the back called "The Temple Of Osiris" was Neal. 
That music he played was a nice complement to the main room's harder/
faster beats. ( it was a minor disappointment to me that they weren't
going to do a jungle/drum and bass thing as listed in the SFRcalander. 

 The MANTRA flyer emphasises the "psychedelic" aspect of the music, and 
that was obvious in the music I heard this Sunday. I, and a lot of other 
folks , were definitely transporting! I would recommend that folks check
out this weekly - I live in Sunnyvale, so I had to make MANTRA a special
event that I may not repeat too often, although I like my first time there
very much! Doesn't seem as though they need to "get the word out" to 
increase attendance though, as the place was pretty full by 11:30-12:30. 

 Nice dayglo handpainted draperies  , rudimentary visuals without video 
( that was fine with me! ), great dancefloor vibe. 

 Get there early , as parking within a 1/4 block of the club gets filled
early.

 Bye for now -  Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

PS - Hello again to all the SFRaves folks who where at  FF

In-Reply-To: <Pine.SOL.3.91.960625185855.25226A-100000@pluto>

Too bad about the show.....sound wise at least...

I saw them at Organic 96 this past weekend and the sound was superb -
perhaps because they were outdoors with no echos and sound people even 
thought to put in two large (16 cabinets or so each ) sets of "fill" speakers
which were behind the crowd.... the Wicked sound doesn't even come close!
Perhaps large sound companies in LA are better with large concert sound?
This was one concert ( Organic ) that everything was totally clear and the
bass could peel paint.... we did even notice that when DJ's played the 
"compressed" sound of the records was WAY LESS impressive than the live
instruments... so that when Orbital began live the bass was so deep and
loud that it was wonderful.... no record would have been able to track such
strong uncompressed bass....


As for their visuals they were on smaller screens reminding me of eyeglasses
with a center screen - but still very visible and very social-political...

I saw Underworld 1st at this show and I would agree that while they play
a fast easy to dance to set - they were no where near the quality of
Orbital.... As far as I'm concerned Orbital upstaged everyone at Organic
so that the Orb - who played last- were anticlimatic....

I imagine Orbital played first at the Filmore because it was a work night
and they wanted more of the crowd to be there- figuring a lot of people
would leave early to get ready for work?


I also liked how Orbital played in the dark with their flashlight headsets
at Organic which made them look sort of like "glowing eye" aliens in the
darkness....


Mike



 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & ecstatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

Hi Milton.. Do a partial (custom) install of System (7.5) Update 2.0.. It

it doesn't matter that you are running 7.1.. but just to be safe, you can 
install onto another -non-startup disk..

Wow! If you hoped to get a truly 'rave'-like experience at a club show, I
think you were expecting too much. Sure you can have misgivings about the
fillmore, but at least there was somewhere to have it which fit into teh
band's busy schedule. 

Sure the sound wasn't crisp and perfect, *shrug* still, that didn't ruin
the show for me- Orbital did a good job- It seemed like almost everyone
there was dancing (seems like a good vibe to me) and sometimes you could
hear the crowd cheering over the loud breaks as well as the soft spots.

As for the temperature of the show, I wore my big jacket until I'd danced
for an hour and was getting way too hot. But the fillmore was never
'sweltering'. Compared to most clubs I go to this was a real nice change of
pace in terms of the high ceilings and breathing room. 

The more I think about it, the more I wish Orbital had gone out on a limb,
but I got what I paid for- a good time.
-Alex

> 
> (chris@ncafe.com)
>

Best bet is to:

Use System 7.5.3 (esp. if using a PPC), and Open Transport 1.1.

Mac TCP 2.0.6 has some problems, and is relatively limited as compared to 
OT 1.1.

OT 1.1 comes as part of the 7.5.3 System Software.

CHeck Apple's web page for more details.  Ditch 7.5 or 7.5.2.

Out,
John

Subject: Re: Orbital/Underworld
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I danced more than I ever have at any show or party.  Just could not stop.
Sound was great.  A friend of mine said it was hurting his ears, but I
thought it was quite nice....loud but not too loud.  Clear as a bell was my
impression.  Dj's were great.  I havn't had the desire to move to fast hard
music like that in a long time....once again, could not stop.  Both bands
were excellent...thank you Orbital for playing that slow track off of "The
Box."  Both bands were equally impressive, and either could have played
first and it wouldn't have mattered.  Orbital I think is a little more on
the cerebral side...where Underworld was much more dance oriented.  Both
were great within thier own styles.  Vibe was nice with lots of smiling
faces.  Paul H. was kind enough to come out from back stage to make himself
available for conversation with fans.  He's really nice, and has done the
same thing at all three shows I've seen them at.  Stoked all the way around,
and unlike the Orbital/Moby/Aphex show at the Galleria, I will remember this
show due to sobriety.  I'm sure glad I learned how to have fun this way.  It
seems to last longer :)

Rick

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jun 26 11:32:35 1996

Subject: Orbital/Underworld comments
Reply-To: mayer@netcom.com
Date: Wed, 26 Jun 96 11:32:32 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Comments:
(0) Orbital was awesome. Definitely "intelligent dance music". 

(1) Underworld was lightweight pap in comparison. What the fuck was up
    with the lead singer and his guitar. Seemed like he never played
    it, but just hung on to it in some vein attempt at appearsing people's
    rock and roll sensibilities. That was a big turnoff cuz it made them
    seem so phony and "crossover". I was kinda annoyed by some of their
    "pop" songs -- sounded like the kind of crap I tune-out on Live 105.
    (nonetheless, I danced and enjoyed, but left before their encore
    because they seemed to be going on and on and on without any new tricks
    or sounds. (Unlike orbital).

(2) The sound was WAY TOO LOUD (see more comments on the soundsystem below)
    especially given the fact that they had a soundsystem that blew the
    crap out of most rave systems, if operated properly.

(3) I absolutely HATED the DJ'd music between sets and before Orbital
    came on. I am very happy I arrived late enough to miss most of the DJ
    that played before Orbital -- we got there about 15-20 minutes before
    Orbital played. Sounded like music for crackheads and tweakers. It wasn't
    even "good fast" -- just lame-boring-monotonous-completely-devoid-o'-funk
    fast. Sounds like my diskdrive when I "grep" over my whole
    filesystem, except that at least my diskdrive is doing something
    useful. Blech.

--------------------

Replies to others:

--------------------
> anyway.. the one song that starts of with the father talking to the son
> and saying "and next time you see your mother, say hello to SATAN SATAN
> SATAN SATAN... etc..

Isn't this a sample from a Jello Biafra or Dead Kennedy's song??

The song is called "Satan" -- I recently picked up a used CD at Reckless
Records called "Orbital III" by "Internal Records" which contains "Satan"
"L.C.1" and "Belfast" all done in 1991.

> And there was a tub of fresh *free* APPLES, for crying out loud.

Yep. That's a fillmore tradition. Hell, I've seen so many bands there ...
The Dead, Jerry Garcia, Red Hot Chili Peppers, Jimmy Cliff, Robyn
Hitchcock, The Radiators, The Neville Brothers, George Clinton, etc etc
etc... The Fillmore is steeped in SF rock/psychedelic vibe and I consider
it a "power spot" for music performance (unlike the Trocadero and the
Warfield, which both suck).

> Techno music is, like vynal, sythetic sounds created from a pre-programmed
> memory which means that they were created at a different frequency then if
> they had been composed by live electronic instrument (such as a guitar).
> Therefore, anytime you play sythicated music through a live, rather then
> rave, speaker system it is going to sound like shit no matter how good the
> bands equipment is (and Orbital's equipment was the bollocks; did anyone
> check that out?)  or the venues PA is.

This is complete and utter bullshit. They had an incredible sound system at
the Fillmore (huge phased arrays of Meyer Sound Labs speakers -- hundreds
of thousands of dollars worth of speakers and amps)... the problem was that
the sound people had it turned up so loud that their system was distorting,
so loud that one's eardrums were "distorting". Painfully loud -- as in
shove a napkin in yer ear to keep yer head from exploding loud.

Actually, the sound started off absolutely horrible and got a little better
over the course of the evening. Within 15 mins into the Orbital, they had
managed to defuzz the high end and put some bass through.

(I was right at the stage, on the left hand side, away from the subwoofers.)

When I finally made it back to the mixing board area, I noticed that the
sound was much better there. Nonetheless, the sound guys seemed to want to
see how loud you could get a system like that (kinda like a newbie getting
behind the wheel of a very powerful car and burning rubber thinking they're
being really "cool" and "macho" when in fact they're just wasting power and
traction).

The sound could have been incredible if the sound guys knew what they were
doing. But chances are, they've been playing a bunch of crappy rave sound
systems and never got behind a real soundsystem capable of incredible
finesse and fidelity.

> The least thing that the they vould have done was to have scraped the house
> system and have got the Whicked system in instead which is a) much louder
> and (most importantly) deeper and b) it is operated by people that really
> understand techno music and how to make it sound good; the sound guy for
> the house did not have a clue.

Yes, the sound folks did not have a clue. But guess what, the Wicked sound
system does not compare to the sound system they have at the Fillmore. It
was sacrilege that they couldn't figure out how to get it to sound better.
I have heard a system like that tuned/operated properly and it was AWESOME.
The system at the Fillmore is certainly adequately loud and deep for the
task, as long as you know how to use it. Fact is, it would have sounded
better if it was quieter. LOUD =/= BETTER.

> What I want to know is bearing in mind that the Fillmore made bank and knew
> that they were going to the least thing they could have done was got in a
> few of those large industrial fans to cool the place down.  But oh yeah I
> forgot, there're only interested in our money so what the fuck do they
> care?

I thought the ventilation was SUPERB. Hot enough to catch a vibe, but cool
enough to not make me feel like passing out. Yes, I was drenched in sweat,
but that's normal considering how much dancing I was doing.

> I didn't know that "rave" speaker equipment is any different from Live
> equipment. Last time I looked speaker technology hasn't changed much in 30
> Years, there's not really that much you can do with paper and magnets.

Actually, a lot has changed in 30 years. People have learned about time
alignment and phasing. Crossover technologies have improved --
Biamplification and active crossovers.  New high-tech materials are being
used for speaker elements. New metallurgy technologies have allowed huge
magnetic fields to be induced across the voice coil with smaller and
lighter magnets.  Ferrofluid cooling allows lots of power to be drawn away
from the voice coil and dissipated by the metal magnets and
frames. Composite materials used in the construction of cabinets, and
better tuning of cabinets... Huge advances in sound.

Beyond that, test equipment for sound has gotten a lot better. It was
pretty hard to get a portable real time spectrum analyzer to equalize your
theaters back in the old days. Now you can go down to a pro audio store and
purchase one for less than $10K. They even have systems that will "listen"
to the sound and correct the sound dynamically and automatically.  (e.g. to
correct for sound absorbtion by the crowd, the air temperature, wind, etc).

Take a listen to a Meyer Sound Labs (IMHO the best speakers on the planet)
system versus one of those old "Electrovoice -- Voice of the Theater"
speakers used back in the 40's-70's. There's a dramatic difference in
clarity, imaging, and "spaciousness" of the sound that wasn't possible in
the old days.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==    Niels Mayer ..... mayer@netcom.com ..... http://www.eit.com/~mayer   ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

> > anyway.. the one song that starts of with the father talking to the son
> > and saying "and next time you see your mother, say hello to SATAN SATAN
> > SATAN SATAN... etc..

If the sample is:

"Daddy, what's regret mean?  Well son, a funny thing about regret is;
it's better to regret something you have done than to regret something
you haven't.  And by the way, next time you see your mother, be sure
and tell her...  SATAN! SATAN! SATAN!"

then that's the _Butthole Surfers_ back when they made awesome (literally!)
music you wouldn't hear on commercial radio.

Tim

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jun 26 13:16:23 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA02493; Wed, 26 Jun 1996 13:16:23 -0700
Received: from xinet.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA02487; Wed, 26 Jun 1996 13:16:20 -0700
Received: from [131.106.1.76] by xinet.COM via SMTP (940816.SGI.8.6.9/931108.SGI.ANONFTP)
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.com> id NAA02693; Wed, 26 Jun 1996 13:16:17 -0700
Message-Id: <v02140b0dadf7283e6703@[131.106.1.76]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 26 Jun 1996 13:16:14 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: tifred@xinet.COM (Ti-Fred Torres)
Subject: some thoughts about orbital
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I've always liked orbital, but at the same time I've always felt like I
didn't quite get their message.  After seeing them at the Fillmore, I feel
like I know a little more about them and I thought I'd share it.

Toward the end of their set, they played some great song that made me
really happy--SATAN? Halycon? I'm not sure.  It was a song rich in funky
beats, changes, melodies, humor and power.  In short, it reminded me how
powerful and interesting techno music is and how I love the feeling of
being absorbed into a rave.

THEN, they played a song I didn't recognize that was much slower and less
"distinctive."  I stopped dancing and watched the screens.  They were
flashing images of people walking down city streets, hurriedly,
distractedly.  The overall feeling was of confused and compulsive movement,
or maybe of a conspiracy of silence between everyone. This struck me as a
very familiar feeling.  And why not? the images could have been filmed on
any old street corner.  They could have been filmed outside the Fillmore
earlier that day.  They were scenes we see and participate in every single
day.

Seeing that made me think orbital was taking a moment to remind us about
what our lives are like outside of raves.  In the rave, we can be fully at
attention and drawn together, but outside of them, an overriding
distraction and distance and non-communication is the norm.

It struck me how perfect it was to play this song AFTER a really up-tempo
song--as if orbital wanted to put our excitement about raving into
perspective.  And then it didn't seem like a slow, undistinctive song
anymore--it was a reflective song and sort of sad --maybe not sad, I don't
know--but very rich and interesting.

The song really got under my skin and gave me a feeling that is hard to
describe, but it wasn't the power of raging techno.  When I saw the
pictures I recognized my life--how I walk around streets just like everyone
else, along with everyone else, distracted like everyone else.  The song
seemed to be alerting me/us to this fact.  It wasn't a judgement or the
films would have been flashing the words "WAKE UP!" or something.  It was
more like it was showing us an aspect of life we all know and asking--"What
is going on here?  What sense does this make?  Why does it happen?"  The
tone of the music made me feel like the images were pointing more towards a
question then a conclusion.  So I guess the feeling I got was a gentle sort
of questioning towards our world.  To me, that is a rare and special
feeling because my first reaction to our world is always to feel bitter and
helpless.

With that song, Orbital made a link in my mind between the feeling of being
absorbed in a rave and being absorbed into distractedness outside of raves.
It was like Orbital had given us two feelings to chew on: raving, which
can feel definitively good, and non raving, which can feel ambiguous and
strange.  They were posing the feeling of non raving as a question--"what
is up here?  How does it feel to be part of it?" --and that made me feel
like I could move in the world a little differently.


Ti-Fred









From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Jun 26 13:30:02 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA04027; Wed, 26 Jun 1996 13:30:02 -0700
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id NAA04004; Wed, 26 Jun 1996 13:29:58 -0700
From: Sami Khoury <khoury@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <199606262029.NAA04004@taz.hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: Orbital/Underimpressed
To: jfogler@itsa.ucsf.EDU (jess)
Date: Wed, 26 Jun 1996 13:29:57 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <Pine.A32.3.93.960625215121.93309A-100000@itsa.ucsf.edu> from "jess" at Jun 25, 96 10:03:53 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL24]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 1043      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Orbital played a set that was largely verbatim off their new CD - I
> mean note for note, no mixing, no playing around, no nothing - they
> seemed to be jumping around a lot in order to hide the fact that they had
> nothing to do on stage except press play occasionally.

You must not have been paying very close attention :)

Every time a 303 line came in, one of the Orbitalites would start
tweeking it, playing around with the filter cut-off and resonance,
and you could hear the sound change accordingly.

They were also playing around with the mixer the whole time.  You may
have noticed numerous instances where the beat was suddenly swathed
in reverb or delay for a single hit, and then back to normal, or some
playing around with stereo effects, or some tweeking on the Jupiter 6.

Someone mentioned they left before Underworld came back on for their
encore.  *big mistake*  I'll admit that I was getting a little bored
with their set towards the end, but this last song, "Cowgirl" I believe,
absolutely kicked.  I went nuts.

	Sami

SATAN...SATAN...SATAN"

>

>"distinctive."  I stopped dancing and watched the screens.

The song after the encore was "Halcyon + on + on" . I know because its one
of my favorite Orbital tracks, and is off the Second Album (Brown cover).  I
saw on the Orbital mailing list that Halcyon was the name of an
anti-depressant prescribed in the 60's to their mom. 
I tnink the track is both sad ( & beautiful), as is most of the new album.
Especially track 5 .I put it on when i got home yesterday and just thought
it was amazing how much emotion can be conveyed without words......
