Hey y'all!


>> What's this Mantra.  Is this a weekly on Sundays?  Hmmmm can I get more
>> info on this from anyone. I'd like to check it....if the trancedance is
>> nice...
>
> The trancedance is AMAZING! 


Regarding this Mantra thing..


Mantra happens every Sunday from 10p to 3a.

It's put on by Phillip (aka Theta Blip), Starbuck, Surge, Jennifer and many
others.

For clarity, the lineup was Dutch, then Ceiba (a Kode IV side project wich
includes Peter Z. and DJ Caban a.k.a Adam), who played live and Dj'd.

Adam used to be with F-8, but is now partners with myself and some friends
at our new distribution company, Hunab Ku.   


> The MANTRA flyer emphasises the "psychedelic" aspect of the music, and 
>that was obvious in the music I heard this Sunday. I, and a lot of other 
>folks , were definitely transporting! I would recommend that folks check
>out this weekly - I live in Sunnyvale, so I had to make MANTRA a special
>event that I may not repeat too often, although I like my first time there
>very much! Doesn't seem as though they need to "get the word out" to 
>increase attendance though, as the place was pretty full by 11:30-12:30. 


"Psychedelic" is definitely the word! As Hunab Ku, we're shying away from
the word "Goa" trance, and  using the term "psychedelic". It seems to be
much more appropriate for what we're doing. Especially since now the music
we're carring is coming from all over the world (literally)!


Stay tuned for some upcoming releases...

KODE IV/Ceiba - Moon and the Sun remix, Superstition Records, GR, due in August
Ceiba SF compilation CD - due out end of August on Ceiba Records, SF
Ceiba - Firestarter 12", Ceiba Records, SF

>
> Nice dayglo handpainted draperies  , rudimentary visuals without video 
>( that was fine with me! ), great dancefloor vibe. 


The dance energy was amazing! I planned on going home at 1am, but couldn't
leave because the vibe was sooooo good. I had to be at work at 7am, but it
was worth it!

the info line is 415.331-1500 x. 888

In-reply-to: Your message of "Wed, 26 Jun 1996 11:32:32 PDT."
             <199606261832.LAA14671@netcom10.netcom.com>

From: ozymandias G desiderata <ogd@organic.com>

Precedence: bulk


  npm == Niels P Mayer <mayer@netcom.com>

  npm> (1) Underworld was lightweight pap in comparison. What the fuck was up
  npm>     with the lead singer and his guitar. Seemed like he never played
  npm>     it, but just hung on to it in some vein attempt at appearsing
  npm>     people's rock and roll sensibilities. That was a big turnoff
  npm>     cuz it made them seem so phony and "crossover". I was kinda
  npm>     annoyed by some of their "pop" songs -- sounded like the kind
  npm>     of crap I tune-out on Live 105.  (nonetheless, I danced and
  npm>     enjoyed, but left before their encore because they seemed to
  npm>     be going on and on and on without any new tricks or
  npm>     sounds. (Unlike orbital).

I'll leave your assessment of Underworld's songwriting talents alone,
because I know well how differently people regard Underworld. I happen to
like the vocals and the more pop feel they bring to some of their songs,
and have a hard time imagining Underworld on Live 105. But I will say, as
Brendan did earlier, that Karl was using the guitar to control the
frequency input of a vocoder. You can hear it more clearly on the album.
He basically was just playing one chord, but occasionally he would
switch, for effect. A neat trick, albeit a neat trick taken straight from
the progressive rock of the late 70s.

  npm> (2) The sound was WAY TOO LOUD (see more comments on the
  npm>     soundsystem below) especially given the fact that they 
  npm>     had a soundsystem that blew the crap out of most rave systems,
  npm>     if operated properly.

No shit. The distortion on the treble was the worst, because it turned
merely loud music into shrieking walls of distortion, which can be cool
in its own right, but I don't think was the effect that Orbital were
reaching for. Plus it left my ears feeling sorely abused the next day and
had me thinking nervously about hearing damage.

  npm> (3) I absolutely HATED the DJ'd music between sets and before
  npm>     Orbital came on. I am very happy I arrived late enough to 
  npm>     miss most of the DJ that played before Orbital -- we got there
  npm>     about 15-20 minutes before Orbital played. Sounded like music
  npm>     for crackheads and tweakers. It wasn't even "good fast" --
  npm>     just lame-boring-monotonous-completely-devoid-o'-funk
  npm>     fast. Sounds like my diskdrive when I "grep" over my whole
  npm>     filesystem, except that at least my diskdrive is doing
  npm>     something useful. Blech.

:p Darren Price's mixing was one of my favorite things about the whole
show. His music may have been repetitive and devoid of funk, but both of
those things can be good, when employed properly. Machine music has its
own aesthetic, as do the harder sounds that we don't normally get to hear
in San Francisco. I personally thought Darren Price's set was the
antithesis of lame and boring, but I also thought that it was the
antithesis of the typical SF sound (whatever the hell _that_ means these
days). Take from that what you will. And, for the record, I'm straight
edge and always have been. Although I've heard it said that I somehow
manage to be a tweaker just the same.

  >> anyway.. the one song that starts of with the father talking to the son
  >> and saying "and next time you see your mother, say hello to SATAN
  >> SATAN SATAN SATAN... etc..
  npm> 
  npm> Isn't this a sample from a Jello Biafra or Dead Kennedy's song??

It's by the Butthole Surfers and is, I believe, from the _Hairway To
Steven_ LP.

  npm> The song is called "Satan" -- I recently picked up a used CD at Reckless
  npm> Records called "Orbital III" by "Internal Records" which contains
  npm> "Satan" "L.C.1" and "Belfast" all done in 1991.

"Satan" also appears on Orbital's debut LP, simply entitled _Orbital_
(it's been dubbed "the Green Album" to distinguish it from the also
untitled "Brown Album", which was Orbital's second LP). Anybody who was
impressed by Orbital's set Monday night and who doesn't already own the
Green and Brown albums should run right out and buy them. They're both
definitive techno classics.

  >> The least thing that the they vould have done was to have scraped 
  >> the house system and have got the Whicked system in instead which is
  >> a) much louder and (most importantly) deeper and b) it is operated
  >> by people that really understand techno music and how to make it
  >> sound good; the sound guy for the house did not have a clue.
  npm> 
  npm> Yes, the sound folks did not have a clue. But guess what, the
  npm> Wicked sound system does not compare to the sound system they have
  npm> at the Fillmore. 

No shit. I don't know what's up with the preposterous amount of
veneration that the Purple People Pusher gets in SF. I've been a lurker
on this list for years and years, and heard the hype about the new Wicked
system before they even bought it. I was completely psyched about getting
a chance to hear it, and was then very disappointed when I finally
did. IMHO, the Wicked system lacks punch and clarity, both of which are
things I value over sheer volume and gut-wrenching bass. Maybe I'm just
getting old, but as a DJ, I prefer the music to sound something like what
the artist recorded, and not a woofy muffled caricature of same.

  >> What I want to know is bearing in mind that the Fillmore made bank 
  >> and knew that they were going to the least thing they could have
  >> done was got in a few of those large industrial fans to cool the
  >> place down.  But oh yeah I forgot, there're only interested in our
  >> money so what the fuck do they care?
  npm> 
  npm> I thought the ventilation was SUPERB. Hot enough to catch a vibe, 
  npm> but cool enough to not make me feel like passing out. Yes, I was
  npm> drenched in sweat, but that's normal considering how much dancing
  npm> I was doing.

Yeah, I completely didn't get this comment. I was dancing as hard as I
ever have all night long and actually noticed at several points in the
evening how cool it was for a place that crowded. Of course, that might
have been because I was standing towards the back, but really, it wasn't
that bad.

anywhere, just a few more random comments,
ozymandias

mayer@netcom.com wrote:

>    Sounded like music for crackheads and tweakers. It wasn't
>    even "good fast" -- just lame-boring-monotonous-completely-devoid-o'-funk

Y'know, it's funny you mention that.  I've noticed lately that doing a 
"dir/s/o-d" of my 16 gig Maxtor external drive (so big it comes with it's 
own ZIP code) it makes this cool, bip-buzz-zupzup sound that's got a 
trancey/ambient/jungle-sans-bass feel to it.  Lately I'll do a "dir" just 
for the heck of it and sit in my chair, bopping and snapping my fingers to 
that funky beat...

didn't know is probably a sign that you're a healthy person! :-)

from 7am-330pm m-f, and go to Heald Intstitute of Technology from
600pm-1035pm m-f. About the only thing that makes me unwind is dancing like a
maniac until the wee hours of the mornin. 
        I'm just seein if anyone might want to go with me every whenever so I
won't be alone. I usually drive, and if possible, I can usually take 3 or 4
other people. As long as you're cool, have a clean vibe, and don't mind being
around friendly people, you're allright with me.

On Wed, 26 Jun 1996, Jon Zimmerman wrote:
 
>   Therefore, anytime you
> >play sythicated music through a live, rather then rave, speaker system
> >it is going to sound like shit no matter how good the bands equipment is
> >(and Orbital's equipment was the bollocks; did anyone check that out?)
> >or the venues PA is.
>   I didn't know that "rave" speaker equipment is any different from Live
> equipment. Last time I looked speaker technology hasn't changed much in 30
> years, there's not really that much you can do with paper and magnets.
 
        Actually there is a lot you can do with paper, kevlar, aluminium,
other alloys, steel, copper wire, plywood and alot has changed in the last
30 years...  Take a listen to the EAW 325 cabs that are making their way 
out to parties these days. Better yet, stand right up at the them but off
to the side and than walk in front and around to the other side. Those
things throw in an amazingly wide arc! But that was not the point being
refuted.
 
        The point that was being made was that the house sound engineer at
the Fillmore was tuning the noise for a live band instead of for techno  
because many sound engineers who work with live bands and exclusively live
bands do not understand techno and for some reason, crank the mids and   
highs to painful levels which has the effect of totally killing the music
for many people. If you can aren't affected by levels being tweaked
poorly, consider yourself lucky...
 
        Whether or not one likes tristan's presentation of his point, one
doesn't have to get all defense about the SF scence. No one seemed to
have taken great offense to someone calling dark, hard techno shite. But
as soon as the SF vibe comes under attack, people are throwing their arms
in the air yelling and screaming. There are things we have to learn from
the british (or maybe more to the point, the Scottish festi...) vibe, and
there are things that they could take from SF. So before attacking the
"outsider", why don't we see what he's talking about?
 
dave

In a previous mail, Niels P. Mayer wrote:
> 
> (3) I absolutely HATED the DJ'd music between sets and before Orbital
>     Sounded like music for crackheads and tweakers. It wasn't
>     even "good fast" -- just lame-boring-monotonous-completely-devoid-o'-funk
>     fast. Sounds like my diskdrive when I "grep" over my whole
>     filesystem, except that at least my diskdrive is doing something
>     useful. Blech.

	No shit! I could have gone then!! :)

	According to another review, it was tracks from Reload, uh? 
	Sounded like greppin' a filesystem? But man, you should know that 
	actually the Reload artists are the only ones of the planet who
	use Unix for their stuff...
	Try it yourself: grep a defragmented partition near the border of the
	disk: you get a low zouik-zouik sound. Grep a fragmented partition
	close to the center of the disk: kwik-kwik-kwik. Do both of them,
	alternatively suspending/resuming the grep jobs or adjusting their
	respective priority, add some beats, a bassline of 303, and a good 
	infrabass booming sound... 
	_THIS_ IS TECHNO!!! ;-)
	
> [sound system]

	I can only agree: I actually heard the same good sound system in 
	the same location twice, for two different raves, tuned by two 
	different teams: it was completely different, I hardly believed 
	that the stuff involved was the same!
	The *tuning* makes a HUGE difference!!

	And I've been once in my life to a rave setup and organized by
	real concert professionnals: awesome, the sound was crisp and clear
	and still bumping and loud while not hurting... Definitely different.
	A _free_ great fucking massive guys, incredible.

Renaud

------- End of Forwarded Message

My friend spent the whole night working on an emergency in downtown 
San Francisco.  At 5:30 am he went out to his car to move it, and found 
that it was ticketed for being parked in a tow-away zone.  The problem? 
The space was not to become a tow-away zone until 6 am!  He called 
the Police Dept., and of course, they can't take a report, and suggested 
that he just go to Traffic Court and tell the judge.  So even though he 
was in the right, he has to lose half a day's wages to report the SF 
Parking "error."

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

feel free to spread this around, add to it, or whatever. it came from my
friend thadius on mt. shasta...



>Grafitti
>
>God is a circle whos center is everywhere but whos circumference is nowhere
>For further information consult your Pineal gland.
>If you don't care where you are, then you are not lost.
>My inner child can beat up your inner child.
>Just to be is a blessing
>Just to live is holy
>You live and learn. Or you don't live long.
>We learn from history that we don't learn from history.
>Dare to be Stupid.
>Time is an illusion perpetrated by the manufacturers of space.
>He who lives without folly is less wise than he believes.
>If you can't beat 'em..........there not tied down properly!
>Don't look now but there is a multi-legged creature on your shoulder.
>He who hates vice hates mankind.
>You can't be late until you show up.
>To become divine is to become attuned in thought feeling and act to the
>whole of creation
>I wish you humans would leave me alone.
>The door is the key.
>Change your thoughts and you change your world.
>Troubles are like babies they only grow by nursing.
>Question Authority--and the Authorities will question you.
>You have been selected for a secret mission.
>Any priest or shaman must be presumed guilty until proven innocent.
>Do not merely believe in miracles, rely on them.
>Be excellent to each other.
>Animals can be driven crazy by placing too many of them in a pen.The man
>who makes no mistake does not usually make anything.
>Second star on the right and keep going til dawn.
>Fine, DON'T have a nice day, see if I care.
>In this life we are to become heaven, so that God might find a home here
>The only difference between a rut and a grave is their dimensions.
>But I don't like Spam!!!
>Don't take life to seriously, you'll never get out of it alive.
>Confidence: a feeling peculiar to the stage just before full comprehension
>of the problem.
>There are trivial truths and there are great truths.  The opposite of a
>trivial truth is plainly false. The opposite of a great truth is also
>true.
>
>Those students who have become one with the Universe will be allowed to go
>on and become two with the universe.
>
>Every absurdity needs a champion to defend it.
>The meek will inherit the Earth .  The rest of us will go to the stars.
>Wonders never cease, as long as you never cease to wonder.
>It is better to die on your feet than live on your knees.
>It's easier to fight for one's principles than to live up to them.If it's
>comprehensible its obsolete.
>And the less I seek my source for some definitive, the closer I am to fine...
>I live like this because I like it. I've seen to much to pretend.
>So...so you think you can tell...heaven from hell.
>I've come along way since I believed in anything.
>Truly the road to Enlightenment is like unto a half mile of broken glass.
>Reality is the temporary result of the struggle between rival gangs of
>programmers.
>I...I believe in love.
>You can't lick the system, but you can certainly give it a damn good fondling!
>I didn't claw my way to the top of the food chain to eat vegetables!
>Secret to long life and prosperity: don't spin too fast.
>You mean, you need drugs to hallucinate?

>brings total obliteration. I will face my fear.  I will permit it to pass

>see its path.  Where the fear has gone there will be nothing. Only I will
>remain.

when the Wayman Bros. were the writers/producers.  I do like MAD TV now 
though so...) in an Arsenio Hall skit done by Keenan Ivory Wayans.  The 
shit was ON!  He was apeing Arsenio with a larger than usual buttocks, 
one huge long finger, and Arsenio's extra toofy smile.

"Mmmm, MMM!  Judge, you so fine, I'df like to pour bar-bee-que sauce all 
over you and work ya like a rib!!!"

Hahahahahhaha, damn that shit was on!

is called a "blue moon" ), it would be extra-special to attend a full
moon event this weekend! Also, since it's so soon after last weekend's
solstice time.

events on sfraves, but maybe if there's anything happening outdoors that

Message-Id: <9606272147.AA01528@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
Subject: in memory of a friend
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Thu, 27 Jun 96 14:47:23 PDT
Cc: jlf3@mofo.com, greysix@netcom.com, bob@csp.org
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

David Sarlin, a friend of many within and outside the Bay Area rave 
scene, passed away from our world this morning.  For those of you
who didn't know him, you've probably seen him around; he had been a
regular at Sunsets, ComeUnity, FMRs, Gatherings, etc. for many years.
He was a bit older than most of us, 50's, short ponytail, dressed with 
a 60's flair.  He was known for his generosity, wisdom and a warm aura
of love.  Over the years he had rented out or just shared his Berkeley
home with many of us.  In the end, words cannot do justice in summing 
up this wonderful person's life.

David died of complications due to kidney failure.  Although he did
have the option of fighting a difficult, uphill, medical battle, he
chose to die according to his own will.  The amount of love I witnessed
from people who visited him during his last days - a wide range of people 
he had touched over the years - was amazing.  The peace he exuded along
with the harmony he shared concerning his path forward into the Great 
Unknown was nothing short of inspirational.  He left the bulk of his
estate to environmental and medical charities.

When the dialysis nurse asked him what his religion was, he replied,
"Psychedelics, Buddhism, Judiasm."  When Janie & I last visited him
about a week ago, he explained his serenity to us in terms of the
Buddhist way of transcending suffering, which is to let go of Desire.
He spoke to us of Judiasm, about the concept of the One:  the one 
God/Spirit/Force that exists in all things, that connects us all to each
each other and to Nature.  And he mentioned how his use of psychedelics 
had made it easier for him to realize all of this.  I told him that yes,
there are things that transcend life-and-death, and because of that
we will never be truly apart.

David was one of those who could always be seen dancing at the end of
whatever party he was at, his arms still flailing, head still jerking 
while those less than half his age had long since retired.  It seems to
me that even now, David continues to dance for all of us.

Lee
_________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com

I've added a lot of new stuff this week, thanks to a lot of people
emailing stuff in, and handfuls of flyers from Haight St.  Lotsa
good stuff, day and night, this weekend.  Check out Derrick May at
Nikita on Friday, or really anything - it's all good.  There should
be a Sunset boat party on Sunday too, get tix at Ameba if there are
any left - or go to Mission Rock if you miss the boat...

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning 3am-6am - "Aural Fixation"
       experimental sounds of ambient and trip hop with a splash of hi
       nrg, from trance to jungle. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Thursdays 9:30pm-midnight - "Aurora Borealis" Beats and
       atmospherics w/DJ Seth. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
   For a _search_ interface to the calendar, see the Late Train club
   section (http://www.hyperreal.com/zines/late/clubs/).
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Subject: looking up once in a while
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Did anyone see the night sky in San Jose last night at about 11pm?

The moon was almost full, and there were these little fluffy clouds all
aroud it, and you could see the night sky perfectly between the clouds. The
clouds were all white and blue,  and the sky behind them was pitchblack. It
was

    ---> SO BEAUTIFUL <---

I haven't seen a sky like that in five years.

I stood on my neighbor's front driveway with my head thrown back for a few
minutes in complete awe.

yes, you are right :)

Webster Definition for "palindrome"

pal.in.drome \'pal-*n-.dro-m\ n [Gk palindromos running back again, fr. palin back, again +
dram]ein to run;
akin to Gk polos axis, pole - more at POLE, DROMEDARY : a word, verse, or sentence (as "able was I
ere I saw
Elba") that reads the same backward or forward

>>>Seeing that made me think orbital was taking a moment to remind us about
>what our lives are like outside of...<<<
>
>Couldn't agree with you more.  Although those visuals wouldn't have been
>appropriate at any party, it was great to absorb them as a head check, in an
>environment where generally people were a bit more sober and open to that
>sort of holistic perspective.
>-StEvEo
>
I disagree that the visuals wouldn't have been appropriate at any party;
I've seen (and read posts about) some pretty sobering footage of the
harsher realities present in our world, in our society and in other
societies.  It's a very relevant thing to address to a gathering of people
interested (hopefully) in spreading the love and positive energy and sense
of community & connectedness with our sisters and brothers who are sorely
in need of any sort of kindness.  While the wealthy hoard wealth, the
non-wealthy suffer.  This applies to love and compassion, the most
important things in life, infinitely more than it applies to money.  Think
about it.  You love your friends and family, right?  Do you ever express
your love for humanity by extending kindness to a stranger, especially one
who is in some way downtrodden?  Do you do this because it's your way, or
do you need a subtle (or blatant) reminder every once in a while?
I hope to see more footage like this in the future.  NIN uses some pretty
disturbing stuff during live performances of one song (what's it called?),
scenes of devastation, death, decay.  It's a slow song.  Watching that
brought tears to my eyes when I saw them at the SJS Event Center.

Love to everyone,

Eric P.

Eric P. Peterson
Financial Assistant, Materials Management
Network & Computing Services
Synopsys, Inc.

Subject: Re: the word for the day is....
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

See. . . this morning I was driving to work when a small furry multi-legged
creature ran out in front of me on Old Hicklovinearpickinsnotspitten road. I
slammed on my brakes only to just miss the poor thing and drive off the road
into a field of tiny little pickle looking things. My golf cart was stuck so
I got out into the pickle-like field and started walking back towards the
road. About three feet away from the road I found a  fried meat product
substitute patty concoction and it started talking to me. It told me that it
was late for some type of job interview or something and needed a ride. I
told it that I couldn't really help, but if it hung around with me for a bit
I might be able to work something out. 
           We were walking down the road where we came to some 511 hair
place. The burger product substitute patty thing yelled at me and told be
that it needed something from there. Ok, I guess, so we went into the salon
and immediately a lively young female approached the meat thing and asked
what it needed.And she replied  "A bun. . . gee, I'm sorry sir but you'll
have to leave now, we don't tolerate that language around here." At that time
the burger product substitute thing took a deep breath and said, "Fine, I
guess now I'll have to go shave my nipples and buy a new set of turkey
basters." And they lived happily ever after. . . 

       Aryck

Precedence: bulk


Proving yet again that EVERYTHING is on the Web, check out:
 http://www2.englib.cornell.edu/~at11/old/alex/old/annemarie/palindrome.ht  
ml

for what is claimed to be the world's longest palindrome: 1247 words, and   
over 7600 characters.
I haven't checked it, and I have no idea what it says (it's in French).

Or, if you want a big ol' list, you knew someone had to have it: The   
Palindrome Home Page!
 http://www.ecst.csuchico.edu/~nanci/Pdromes/index.html

Some faves:
 Egad! No bondage!
 Sex at noon taxes.
 "Naomi," I Moan.
 Yo! Banana Boy!
 Naomi, did I moan?
 May a moody baby doom a yam?
 A man, a plan, a canoe, pasta, heros, rajahs, a coloratura, maps, snipe,   
percale, macaroni, a gag, a banana bag, a tan, a tag, a banana
bag again (or a camel), a crepe, pins, Spam, a rut, a Rolo, cash, a jar,   
sore hats, a peon, a canal--Panama!
 "I'm a lasagna!" sang a salami.
 Norma is as selfless as I am, Ron.
 Pus, Dan! Ogre sales use laser gonads up.
 Doc, note, I dissent: a fast never prevents a fatness; I diet on cod.
 To: Dr., et al. / Re: Grub / Ma had a hamburger / Later, Dot.

or this amazing one:
 Are we not drawn onward, we few, drawn onward to new era?

and the classic:
 Evil I did dwell, lewd did I live.

They even have "word palindromes":
 You can cage a swallow, can't you, but you can't swallow a cage, can   
you?

Enjoy!
 -Roy

a man, a plan, a canal: panama!

beatcha by one letter!

What kind of friend is it that makes you feel bad for being involved in 
something that makes you happy and does you no harm?

What kind of lover is it that allows you to say and do and give out of the 
strongest desire for, and the complete assumption of, a close, real, loving 
relationship, for several months, knowing full well they don't feel the same 
way?

What kind of person is it that says they care for you and in the same breath 
puts subtle, continuous pressure on you to change?

Why the hell can't I have pure, harmless, fun without someone mucking around 
in it!!!!

damnitimsof*ckingtiredofhavingtojustifyravingtopeoplethathaveneverbeendontun
derstandandwontallowthemselvestounderstandtheywontlistenandimfeduptheycanall
justgotohellandrottheshittylittleratbastards....

Y'know, I wouldn't give a rat's ass, but it's the people I care about most 
that do these things.  It tears me apart, and I just don't think they 
understand the effect they have, or they don't care enough to ponder it.

I've been raving for a little over six months now, and the last month or so 
has been so weird where my non-rave relationships, and even one of my rave 
relationships, have been concerned.  Some of my non-rave friends have come 
across my rave diary.  The reaction is never good.  And each time I wrestle 
with the idea of taking it down.  But why should I?  It's what I like to do, 
and telling the story is fun.  I'm keeping that record as much for me as for 
the next guy.  Why should I have to defend what it says?

And to top it off, I found out a while back that someone I really cared 
about deeply was simply using me.  Pretty shitty, if you ask me.

In a generally pissy mood,

S

The show didn't draw as well as The Orb, but that was fine because it
wasn't too crowded.  DJ Czech was OK but didn't move the crowd much.
Vapourspace played well but with no spotlight and no really danceable
stuff also didn't get much response, not even any applause when he
finished.  Too bad, because it was a well crafted performance.

Orbital was Serious Fun, all right.  I wasn't overwhelmed like in '93,
but from "Satan" on they pulled out all the stops.  Overall a very good
show.  I'm not too keen on some of the stuff they've been doing lately,
but they are always searching for the good bits in whatever is happening
musically at any given time, and I noticed a fair bit of drum&bass
influence tonight.  They obviously enjoy what they're doing and do it
so well it's hard not to go away with a smile :-)

phred

I have been reading the thread of responses about the roomate that 
doesn't get it and a had a couple of questions for everyone:

1. How can you help people understand, when you won't tolerate people
   that don't understand?

2. If you can't make them understand, how do you come to some to some 
   agreement to agree to disagree?
    
    a. Is this possible?
    b. If it isn't then what?

The reason I ask these questions, is that there are a lot of people out
there that don't understand, and have no desire to understand. Our 
society is moving away from "live and let live." Whether it is the 
government, the media, or some commission on morality, society is mucking 
about in all of our personal and private lives and it doesn't seem like 
it is going to stop anytime soon. Can there be a truce?

                                  Feeling a little philisophical,

                                      Black Adder

>>

>Yes, you are indeed correct!  That is a palindrome, the longest one 
>being "Able was I ere I saw Elba".

Actually, the longest palindrome, according to Guinness, is 44,444 words
long, made by Edward Benbow of Bewdley, England.

It starts with, "Anon, now, even odder, I have made lines..."
It finishes with, "...Senile dam Eva, Hired Don. Eve won, Nona.

-G-

Hi Sports Fans!
Traditionally, the saturday before the Pride Parade and Celebration is 
called "Pink Saturday" and the whole Castro neighborhood is closed off to
traffic  so that thousands may gawk and strut, so . . . 

My friend Clay and I are invading with a sound system so that we may 
have dancing in the streets
The event is sponsored by The Sisters of Perpetual Indulgence and they 
ask for a dollar donation which goes to various AIDS groups

We plan to be blasting from 8 to midnite at the corner of 18th and Castro
and given the crowd we'll be spinnning everything from old school disco
to Goa (Yes, this will allow me to play my Doris Day record :)

DO come up and say Hi!

Jim Cyr

Message-ID: <Pine.SGI.3.93.960628085443.22031A-100000@shellx.best.com>

Precedence: bulk

Most DJ's liket o keep their records secret- but seeing as most of what I
buy is readily available to and discerning buyer, I don't see why I
shouldn't share it with you. Besides, what's the point in having a secret
if you can't tell anyone. Here it goes: Purchases for this week...

Domestic:
Robert Hood: The Pace

  New 12" from the king of the minimal nation on M-Plant. Definately some
of his best recent work. A-side is a sparce drum groove with a groovy stab
which subtley tweaks itself over 7 minutes. Definately a winner for Detroit
fans. People unfamiliar with the vibe might find it boring. B-side is a
quieter track, but nice and trippy.

Millstart- The Purposemaker 

  I don't know a whole lot about this new Axis 12". I assume it's Jeff
Mills, but could be wrong. This new purposemaker is bursting with heavy
dancefloor vibes. Clattering high-hats and almost tribal vocal samples make
this a winner. The thing that always gets me about Detroit tracks
(especially axis) is the editing of the tracks. Sure, Jeff Mills never
plays a song for longer than 2 minutes and then spins out of the mix, but
in the US (especially the west coast) we are known for our smooth flawless
mixing. So the short tracks and badly-placed fade outs at the end tend to
get on my nerves.

Jungle:

Photek- Hidden Camera 2x12"

What's up? $12.95 for a double 12"?? I'm in heaven! This new offering from
Rupert Parks is nothing new. But that really doesn't matter when it comes
to Photek. He's so fucking prolific with the high-hats...so bursting with
emotion that you have to sit back and gawk. This offering has three nice
haunting tunes-all equally good- and one down-tempo breakbeat track (like
139 downtempo). I could spin a while just with the Photek I've bought in
the last 7 months, but more and more, this is headphone music for me.

Nightmares on Wax- Stars rmx

Wow- I love walking straight to the downtempo section of a store and
lloking for Jungle remixes. Some of the most innovative stuff out there is
coming out on Ninja Tune, Mo' Wax, Cup of Tea, etc...  This 12" is on Warp
and has two redo's off the Smoker's Delight album. Scruff's job is wicked!
About 90 bpm with little filtered tribal drums which could be excellent in
a hip-hop set. The A-side remix of Stars is my real surprise. I'm not
really one for vocal drum'n bass tracks, but when one pops up that I like,
I'll be listening to it nonstop for days. Stars starts off with a weird
little gypsy violin and then breaks straight into the vocal line. The drums
are mellow, the strings are sweet, and the message is 100% POSITIVE. Though
there's plenty of good jungle in every genre (intelligent, hardstep, jazzy,
etc..) I'm getting  tired of some of the lame gangster samples which DON'T
reflect inner city life, but just glorify violence. So it's a breath of
fresh air to hear a line like ,"God give me stars to reach for, you gotta
give me stars"...high fives all around...


Well, I know it was scant, but I've been poor as of late...it's ok..just
makes me more selective :)

-peace- Alex (DJ Awaza)

[ to sfraves mailist ]

To summarize:

 To date, folks have mentioned two different Full (Blue) Moon events
happening this weekend. 

 The Wicked crew will be doing theirs Saturday night. Another group will
be doing theirs Sunday night, approx. 2 hours driving time from SF. 

 Both groups want to keep the news of their blue moon events to word-of-
mouth (WOM) to limit crowd size. Oh well ...

 As an alternative to the folks outside of the underground WOM loop(s) ,
here's an idea I had :

 On Sunday, get some of your friends together at a park or the beach and 
have your own little full blue moon ceremony , or at least do some moon 
watching - per the astronomers, it's at it's fullest at 8:59 PM.  
Then, with lots of time left over , check out one of the special events 
or weeklies happening on Sunday night. The event/weeklie promoters will
appreciate your attendance, and maybe someone in the crowd will give
you a hint about any outdoor things happening! 

( from Derek Chung's calendar )

 [ Special Events ]

   Sunday, June 30th - Bulletproof presents _Mission Rock_
   Jeno, Garth, Kevin, Flavo, Roman, George, James, Alex, Masami.
   Visuals by Dimension Se7en.

I can't believe that my meager body is still up and about.  I can't 
believe that I partied myself silly on Monday and Tuesday.  Believe me, 
that's never happened before to this lazy-ass.  And now, the weekend is 
upon me, and I am so thrilled.  I wish life was one giant weekend.

I'm a raver with a mission.  Need my dancing fix.  Need to dawn the 
silver slippers and toss out those sensible shoes.  Need to hear some 
groovin', speedy bpm.  Aaahhh, anticipation, my life story.  Life 
wouldn't be fun without it!! 

That said, I am ready to dawn my alter-ego; the silly riot grrl with the 
need to groove.  Hmm..mad scientist by day, speedy Gonzales by night :P

I'll be seein' some (lots?) of ya'all at 1) Meridian tonight and 2) boat 
party on sunday the funday, forget about monday.

excuse the incessant ramblings, it's just Mr. Hyde on the loose. 

See ya out and about.

-Kay the Wild SEE

Hello everyone,

Yes, as a matter of fact, I can believe that this happened. Once, while at a beach on the American River, I left my car 
parked in a residential area. Careful to park on the correct side of the street; the other side had street cleanig hours posted.
Only to return and find that my car had been ticketed. I thought someone must have made a mistake. Then I struck me,
something looked different. A work crew had come along and installed a whole street worth of signs on my side of the
street. The cement wasn't even set all of the way on the last few. They had them tied in plce with string and little spikes
in the grass. I don't see how the cop who wrote this ticket could have missed the" men working" signs that they put up in my
absence. And if he did, probably figured that I would just pay the ticket anyway, rather than take the time and hassle to 
fight it in court. He was wrong. I took pictures of the whole scene and presented them to the judge. He was none too happy,
having seen 14 other similar cases this week. Apparently, this was not the only new parking zone sceduled for that week.
The city had begun new limited parking restrictions all over the city, in residential  areas next to parks and other recreation 
areas. I think police have become self perpetuating in this duty of parking enforcment. 

TICKET TO EARN REVENUE, TO TICKET, TO EARN REVENUE..........


Take Care,
                        Jason

cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: trippity-hoppity
Date: Fri, 28 Jun 96 19:25:13 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Does anyone know of any local DJs who spin good, mellow trip-hop? I've
> heard a unch of Portishead, Massive Attack and Tricky and I want to own
> more of this smooth trippy music... I want to hook up some good mixtapes.

I just picked up an import CD on a whim "macro dub infection vol 1"
(Virgin Records) which  seems pretty trip hop (about 100 BPM) except
for a few times when it breaks into dubby jungle, or electronic reggae.
Everything from 4-Hero, Mad Professor, Wagon Christ, Earthling (J
Saul), Two Badcard, and even Coil (is this "the" Coil, or just some
imitator), Tricky, etc. Pretty cool. This is available at Amoeba
Records (Berkeley), and Rasputins, and cheaper at the latter.

Also, check out Axiom's "Altered Beats -- Assasin Knowledges of the
Remanipulated" which is stuff by DJ Rob Swift, DJ Krush, DXT (the
artist formerly knows as "DST"), Laswell, Wobble, Bootsy Collins, DJ
Q-Bert, etc. I picked mine up at Rasputin's yesteday used for $9.85 and
there's a few more copies there.

Still deciding where these rank on "essentialness" but they're fun to
listen to in the meantime.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Subject: History of WOM 4 FMs
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 28 Jun 1996 22:59:48 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 3590      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

[ to the SFRaves mailist ]

Subject: A History Of Word-Of-Mouth (WOM) Full Moon Raves 

In private email , someone who attends raves but didn't know all that
many other ravers yet asked me about getting to Full Moon (FM) raves -
 
% I can appreciate your idea about people making their own party, or even 
% supporting the smaller weeklies; but, how does one get on the "right 
% list" of the chosen few in order to be invited to the underground stuff? 

 [ Larry here - my reply follows, with some more text and some deletions.
   Any opinions on this subject is welcome! I just hope it doesn't start
   a flame war or anything - but I do think I'm mostly accurate in what
   I say. Those with with better/different memories and opinions on the
   points I raise should post their knowledge ]

 Well - part of the situation is not your "fault". The amount of folks in 
the area that want to go to a FM can easily overwhelm any one FM put on
by a crew with a good reputation, if that event is common knowledge. So, 
from a short period where the full moon events were "widely" announced
( flyers and info numbers ), the Wicked crew went to a word-of-mouth 
system . The present system gets them just-enough folks, and they see no
need to change it. Other crews who want to do FM events have learned from
the Wicked folks and follow the same system .  Some crews do some limited 
flyering ( like a few hours before the event ). Some crews have little or
no reputation, and annouce more ahead of time.

 I went more often in the days of the big advance-announcement FMs , and
they were HUGE! Easy a thousand folks on a moonlit beach. But that was 
too crazy - overdoses, physological panic from the crowds, cops, too many 
folks screwing up the site and leaving trash. Theft. 

 I eventually stopped trying to attend FMs, mostly because they started
so late, were usually held in the middle of the work week, and were prone 
to getting complications ( ie busted ). A couple of months ago, I helped 
with putting on one with some folks in one of the newer FM crews, but they 
are sitting this weekend out. So, when it comes to finding out about a
particular FM on a particular date, I'm usually without "special" contacts
, as many folks are who are just "starting out" in attending FMs.  

 So , how to get to FMs? Here comes the part where you have more to do, if
you want to. 

1. Get to know more ravers in general. This you are doing now via sfraves.
   As a side-effect , you will get to know folks who are involved with
   the creation of raves. A sub-set of those folks are involved with doing
   FMs , or may do FMs in the future.

2. Make yourself useful. Pitch in to help clean up after the music stops.
   Haul equipment back up the beach and the cliffs to where the cars are
   parked. Talk to the folks who are doing the same - the usual social 
   stuff. 

 For your own sake - don't do 1 or 2 as a cold-blooded attempt to get on the
"secret list". That kind of calculation is bad for your psychic health.
( "Bad karma, dude!" )

3. When you get to know enough of your fellow ravers - get 'em together
   and HOLD YOUR OWN FULL MOON RAVE! Just make sure you have purposes 
   in common and have folks who can organize.

 This #3 is the best! Not only are you doing yourself a favor, but you're
giving others something great to attend and remember as well.
 
 And hey - if you miss out on FMs - just tell yourself "it's just a party".
REALLY!  And there will always be great non-FM raves that will make it 
worth staying in (y)our rave scene.

 Keep yourself happy ...

  Larry

TECHNO  PRIMITIVE  AWARENESS



Bridging the gap between our collective future and our primal past with
the healing power of music and dance.  In this workshop we will explore
the link between the creation of dance music and the manifestation of 
inner peace. 
 
Behind every dance there is a beat that draws us together and lets us
move as one.  When we abandon ourselves to the rhythm, our minds quiet
as we allow the primal energy from within to guide us.  This place of
activated bodily bliss is where we shake loose the preconceived notions
of our conditioning to emerge free of the past, alive in the now and 
ready to embrace the future.

A state of transcendence is attainable by all who enter the dance, 
whether drumming the rhythm, mixing the beats, or creating the movement, 
there is one vibe for all to share.  The energy each person gives, 
brings the group to a higher state of conciousness.  We feel that 
dancing is the secret to saving the planet.  We invite you to join us to
find out why, and learn how to activate others as we blend new 
technologies with archaic rituals to discover the joy and love available
to all in the here and now.



MARK AMEBA is founder of Tribal Future.  Our goal is to dissolve the 
           boundaries between people and nature with the healing power
           of music and dance.

DJ TRACY is a well known DJ and performance artist who loves to share
         the peace she has found behind the turntables.

KALI MA is a visionary yoga practitioner with great insight into the 
        connection between body and spirit.

CRAIG ECKERT is an ardent devotee of the drum.  Schooled by Olatunji, 
             Craig has vast awareness of the link between the beat of 
             the drum and the beat of our heart.




                            WEEKEND  OUTLINE 



FRIDAY  -  Arrive at Harbin  -  Orientation  -  Evening meal.

   After dinner fire circle with drums ( conditions permitting).



SATURDAY  -  Morning Yoga  -  Hot Pools  -  Breakfast.

   Midday seminar exploring drumming skills and mixing technique.

   Afternoon Drum Circle  -  Early Dinner.

   Warm up with atmospheric soundscapes to accompany yoga.

   Build to energetic tribal beats through the peak of the evening.

   Fade intensity to quiet earth centered lounge music until bedtime.



SUNDAY  -  Morning Yoga  -  Hot Pools  -  Breakfast.
 
   Regroup to share insights/observations.  Short hike or meditation.

   Outdoor dancing in upper meadow from mid-afternoon till sunset.

   Bring weekend to a close with feast and final fire circle. 


                  
HARBIN HOT SPRINGS  -  MIDDLETOWN , CALIFORNIA


                    WEEKEND OF JULY  26 - 27 - 28        


INFORMATION AND REGISTRATION       #   415 - 263 - 3915

Subject: There is more than one way...
References: <Pine.BSD/.3.91.960628081817.23419A-100000@value.net>

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Black Adder,

Your incisive questions were well timed in regards to recent posts about
'people who just don't get it' and perhaps hinting on something deeper...
 
> 1. How can you help people understand, when you won't tolerate people
>    that don't understand?

One cannot help people and shouldn't even try to help them if one cannot 
tolerate or try to understand why they think and act as they do. There will
always be more harm done than good. (Look at US Foreign policy).
This is the biggest reason, I think, why people react negatively to 'positive' 
advice. 'Believe in this because whatever you are doing is wrong' -- maybe this is 
what's being interpreted by those we confront w/ our views? In this case, are we any
different from the preachers of religion on the streets? I find it hard for people to 
give up the ways they've been encultured to think and behave when they are confronted
with questions about morality. This poses more questioning: Do we want people to just 
'understand' where we are coming from? Or does the real motivation reside in 
changing people's values and beliefs?  When dealing with human lives, there needs to
be delicate handling of other peoples' culture, background, and lifestyle. Without such
care, we will never get them to empathize with us because we have not done the same for
them. 

> 2. If you can't make them understand, how do you come to some to some
>    agreement to agree to disagree?

The 'agreement to disagree' is implicit in human nature. Sometimes this will need to be 
verbalized for people while others may already know this. 


In dealing with people, there is more than one way to attain a semblence of 
understanding and commonality. The exchange of ideas and viewpoints is one of them.
When we place too much value on the outcome of the experience, we lose sight of the
real goal -- the experience itself.  In Taoist Philosophy, Lao-tzu states this idea 
perfectly " Search for it, and it evades -- seek it not, it comes to you." I think he 
means to live simply w/o much expectations from life or people,  is how we will receive 
more than our desires.
 

Peace,
Tex

"We are confronted with portentous problems which can not be solved just
by providing for our material existence, however abundantly. On the
contrary, progress in this direction is fraught with hazards and perils
not less menacing than those born from want and suffering. If we were to
release the energy of the atoms or discover some other way of developing
cheap and unlimited power at any point of the globe this accomplishment,
instead of being a blessing, might bring disaster to mankind... The
greatest good will come from the technical improvements tending to
unification and harmony..."

Nikola Tesla, from "My Inventions: the autobiography of Nikola Tesla"

now what I want to know is, why has the government still got all of his
note and research that he was conducting when he died CLASSIFIED ? are
they that scared of what might happen if we develop "technical improvements
tending to unification and harmony" ?


b e n   c h u n

ben_chun@community.net
http://www.community.net/~ben_chun/

Tex wrote (in response to Black Adder):
>
> > 2. If you can't make them understand, how do you come to some to some
> >    agreement to agree to disagree?
> 
> The 'agreement to disagree' is implicit in human nature.

Unfortunately, I'd have to disagree with this being "implicit in human
nature"  You mentioned (in the same post) US Foriegn Policy--a perfect
example of the inability to `agree to disagree'.  The excessive number
of morality laws in this country (and most others), the inability for
religions which at their core are so similair (Judaism, Christianity,
Islam) to peaceably coexist, predjudice of all kinds running rampant
throughout humankinds daily lives, cats and dogs running....  Sorry, I
get carried away sometimes.

Now I might go for it being implicit in human survival and
advancement.  But that will require for us to overcome our `nature' and
rely on some good old fashion Compassion and Common Sense--which,
unfortunately, isn't common.

Does this sound like I have no faith in Humankind?

Tim

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Jun 29 19:49:07 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) id TAA02959; Sat, 29 Jun 1996 19:49:07 -0700
Received: from umr.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with ESMTP id TAA02904; Sat, 29 Jun 1996 19:49:02 -0700
Received: from saucer.cc.umr.edu (saucer.cc.umr.edu [131.151.1.58]) via ESMTP by hermes.cc.umr.edu (8.7.5/R.4.16) id VAA15460; Sat, 29 Jun 1996 21:49:02 -0500 (CDT)
Received: from (rkumar@localhost) by saucer.cc.umr.edu (8.6.12/M.3.01) id VAA01401; Sat, 29 Jun 1996 21:49:01 -0500
Message-Id: <199606300249.VAA01401@saucer.cc.umr.edu>
Subject: Meridian
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sat, 29 Jun 1996 21:49:01 -0500 (CDT)
From: "roger kumar" <rkumar@umr.edu>
X-Www-Page: http://www.umr.edu/~rkumar/
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

So we called up the bay area underground voicemail and learned that 
meridian had lost it's space and been transformed to a free outdoor 
party, about 25 miles north of Santa Cruz on Hwy 1. Well, that sounded 
rad, so Franz, an Austrian friend visiting Berkeley for the summer, and I 
headed to the BART station, caught the last train to Freemont, and hooked 
up with Robert Brown, who was so very kind and willing to come and pick 
us up and give us a ride to the party. It was an enjoyable ride, with a 
spectacular view of almost-blue moon shimmering off the ocean, and after 
we passed Half Moon Bay, we started watching the odometer, following the 
voicemail's instructions, and looking for a large pyramid at a 
construction site with "BAU" spraypainted on it. About 23 miles down the 
road, we saw a crew of about 50 ravers hanging out on the side of the 
road. "What's up?" asked I. "Can't find it.." replyed They. The gathering 
was continuously growing as more people drove by and decided to stop, 
asking "got any drugs, any e, any x, anything?" as the sound of inflating 
nitrous balloons filled the air. A group of people explained to us how 
they followed the vmail instructions exactly and couldn't find a 
construction site, a pyramid, or a party. So we doubled back and started 
checking out the little roads along the highway, and finally decided that 
we should go back to the gathering. The raver crew was discussing the 
possibility of calling someone with turntables and starting our own 
party, which seemed better than just sitting around. Several were getting 
annoyed and decided to head back home. We did what we should have done in 
the first place, and went forward. We found the "party" at an unmarked 
location a couple miles ahead, across the road from the ocean in a wooded 
area, and went back to get everyone else parked on the side of the road. 
As we arrived, a large group of people were taking off and we heard 
something like "meet at the safeway in santa cruz for new directions."
After waiting around at the location for maybe an hour (3:30 by now?), 
the guy with the soundsystem showed up and Robert, Franz, and I helped 
carry the speaker to the proposed location, a silly spot with no ocean 
view and too much vegitation. The guys carrying the other speaker were 
told to keep on going, to a different location, but we were told to head 
back. After about 45 minutes of chaos, both speakers and the decks ended 
up at the same spot, and while everyone was giving their opinions on the 
best location, someone finally yelled out "lets set up here!" and all 
the tired kids agreed and we set up the decks and speakers and amps very 
slowly. My back hurt from sitting at a computer for nine hours and then 
carring this speaker back and forth, and even though this spot had no 
view of the moon or the ocean, there was no vegitation for dancing kids 
to trample, so I started helping set up. Feeling wierd after a week of 
sleep deprivation, I took it upon myself to try to speed up the process, 
because no one seemed in charge, and nothing was getting acomplished. 
Then after about 30 minutes I decided it was futile and just took it 
easy. Eventually someone decided to go start the generator, and couldn't. 
It appeared the the spark plug had broken, and no one had a spare, or 
even tools to remove the old one. So I met the Bay Area Underground guy, 
Mosha(?), and for the next hour tried to find a spare plug and a socket 
set. We found a motorbike that looked like it would have the right size 
sparkplug, but the owner was unwilling to part with it. Eventually, we 
located a socket set and spare plugs, but they were too big (carsize). So 
we went back to the generator, and I thought we could hack the old plug 
together so it would spark, but the many people around the generator had 
decided the problem was not the sparkplug, but something else. Mosha(?) 
was all depressed, but was trying very very very hard to get everything 
to work out. About now the sun was comming up so Robert, Franz and I 
headed to the beach to watch the moonset and the sunrise. When we got to 
the beach, the stars and moon had already disappeared and the sun was 
slowly comming up. We wrapped oursleves in blankets and rested and 
smoked and ate too-ripe mangoes. After a while it became apparent that we 
were being closely inspected by an insanely large family of Silly Jumping 
Sand Creatures. But we agreed not to bite each other and they let us 
crash on their sand and I let them play in my shoe. At about 6, a couple 
fisherman showed up to the beautiful empty beach and about 6:30 the sun 
finally made it over the hills and slowly brought warmth and light to the 
waves, the water, the sand, and our bodies, and we could now see the 
Silly Jumping Sand Creatures owned the entire shoreline. About 7'ish we 
got up and I hunted for rocks and washed them in the ocean while trying 
not to get soaked (but wouldn't have minded it). I found this cool 
emerald green shiny rock, and this big green rock with yellow speckles 
that looked like a toad, and various black shiny rocks. We headed back to 
the car and could make out slight sounds of house, so we headed back to 
the party location. A 120V recepticle had been located by a porta-potty 
and the soundsystem had been moved to a location overlooking the ocean. 
The view was incredible, but the "DJ" was trying to mix but ended up just 
playing tracks in succession. About 50-75 people were still left at the 
location and I was happy to see that kids would stick it out until so 
late (never would happen in missouri). After a while of not dancing we 
drove back to the bay area, and found a denny's and had a good breakfast 
with weak coffee. Robert dropped us off at the bart station and franz and 
i headed back to International House.

Despite a total lack of organization and planning, the promoter was a 
good guy. It angered me that he didn't put up the signs he talked about 
in the voicemail directions, because he "didn't see the point". He should 
have changed the vmail message.I feel sorry for the people who drove down 
a couple hours only to find no party and had to head back because they 
couldn't find the spot. The sunrise at the beach made the trip 
worthwhile, and we probably shouldn't have gone back, only to hear a 
silly dj. But bad things happen to parties and promotors. Being so 
unprepared is not a good habit when throwing a party like that, but i'm 
sure he's learned his lesson and his next party will proably be rad.  

please pardon the negativity and all the "ands" in this message. I 
probably will not go out tonight, so you probably won't see me unless you 
come to the lab or want to help me with my laundry. I'll be at the blue 
moon thing though. See you all tomorrow night.

-- 
pJou_|        	                 pgp encrypted fone and mail accepted 
    _l				rkumar@fnord-1.lbl.gov rkumar@umr.edu

and the end of the parade route.  I know that is pretty non-specific,

From: Randy C Cone <randream@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: Harmony at the Beach
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9606292239.A9641-0100000@ese.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



Hi all!!


 Yea, I get the first Harmony review in!!
Party was at Panther Beach. Beautiful location with naked old men running 
around. Music started between 2-3 pm with Greg Sandler spinning. Greg 
just spins the most beautiful, interesting music!! Thanks Greg!! Shilo 
(sp?) was next and probably spun the longest. His set was up and down at 
first but then settled into a nice (but standard) techno groove (with 
some very cool exceptions). Ethan was next and he kept the dance groove 
strong and I felt he raised the energy level a couple of notches. Dutch 
came next and spun to the end (8:30 pm). I've always liked Dutch's sets 
from the days of the underground parties at the Cantina in Santa Cruz and 
this set was just as good. Unfortunately I had to bow out for a minutes 
due to hunger wierdness and came back in time to help carry the speakers 
and amp rack up the hill (ugh!).

 Favorite moments;
 
1) dancing to Greg's beautiful set with bubbles coming from behind me,  
   swooping all around the dance floor. I felt like I was going to leave 
   my body at any moment.
 
2) getting my SFraves laminate. THANKS TERRY. He was so nice as to 
   include a lanyard. I got to meet Adam (lunatic) at that moment. A very 
   nice moment indeed.

3) just meeting some very cool people (Hi Andy and Andrew's friend 
   [Anthema, and I'm certain I'm spelling this wrong. Help me Andrew!]) and 
   seeing some old friends.

4) looking at the rock bridge nearby when the setting sun cast it's long 
   rays upom the textured surface, turning it into this incredible 3D 
   fractal.
 
It is really too bad the beach patrol made the sound system stop at 8:30 
as the very phat moon was just starting to poke up above the horizon 
then. And Dutch was just getting better and better. Sigh.


A great time by the Harmony Crew!!!!!! Thanks Folks. I loves youse guyz!!!


Ran


                              -=*=-
                                ~

found this one yesterday :

Wednesday, July 3. The Promise. Ryde (NYC), Galen, Henrik, Ethan, Surge, 
Andre Lucero, Tracy, Solar, Abstract, Radley, Riche, Sean Murray. &7 
befroe 11PM / $10 after. (415) 974-4391 (415) 273-1622. by Next School & 
Space Children.

the fyler's unique in that it's a straight-up kinko's job, espically 
considering that space children usually do high production cut-out 
color flyers. There's also this a written piece inside intitled "The 
Promise" that I don't have the time or spelling skills necesariy to 
transcribe to you.

I think I only ever made it to a single Progress party. I remember the 
lady on the line making a big deal about the whole tree-hugging, new moon 
worshiping spituality of her raves and just finding a party in the Acme with 
an ice sculpture in the ambient room. Wow. Even so, their heart seemed to 
be in the right place so I kept most of my sarcasism to myself. 

I also remember one of their later outdoor parties, the one on the same 
night as that $20 All Together Now at Big Heart City, never happening due 
to techical problems with the fog. Being one of those people that calls 
the number of aborted parties The Day After just to see how the promoters 
handle damage contoll, I have to say I was impressed with their attitude. 
Instead of making excuses & passing the blame (Lucky Charms) or making 
pompous speachs about how "there will be no need for a refund" (the G.U.N. 
Narnia rave mafia) the girl pretty much accepted responsiblity for 
everything that went wrong, explained the jam she was in for paying expenses 
for out-of town Dj'sthat never got a chance to spin, and then *asked* if 
people could help her out by letting the refund slide. I thought that was 
pretty profesional and showed a lot of class. Chances are, I'll probably 
support them this wednesday.

Tim,

Your reasons for disagreeing are valid, if you see that the world we live in
today and the constructs of society are what you interpret to be human nature.
But some people may see it another way. For example, the balanced ecosystem of
a forest with people living off the land (like the Native Americans) in harmony
with their surroundings is human nature. They live naturally. To go beyond our 'human 
nature' , is to detach ourselves from the essence of life. Once detached, we no longer 
have compassion for others and exercise 'common sense'. We are like machines -- working 
and building for the sake of advancement and progress. Because of advancement and 
'progress', we have come to problems such as overpopulation, the inability of religious 
institutions to peaceably coexist, and the excessive number of morality laws that you 
mentioned. It may seem too overwhelming at times to think of all the things that are 
produced because people have not stayed with their human nature. Human nature is the 
peaceable coexistance with the outside environment as well as the 'inner' environment
(Soul). Human nature and human advancement/achievement are two completely different 
things. 

It seems you may have lost some faith in advancement and progress (with
all the problems you spoke of), but perhaps you still have faith in nature. 

Peace,
Tex




Tim Beauchamp wrote:
> 
> Tex wrote (in response to Black Adder):
> >
> > > 2. If you can't make them understand, how do you come to some to some
> > >    agreement to agree to disagree?
> >
> > The 'agreement to disagree' is implicit in human nature.
> 
> Unfortunately, I'd have to disagree with this being "implicit in human
> nature"  You mentioned (in the same post) US Foriegn Policy--a perfect
> example of the inability to `agree to disagree'.  The excessive number
> of morality laws in this country (and most others), the inability for
> religions which at their core are so similair (Judaism, Christianity,
> Islam) to peaceably coexist, predjudice of all kinds running rampant
> throughout humankinds daily lives, cats and dogs running....  Sorry, I
> get carried away sometimes.
> 
> Now I might go for it being implicit in human survival and
> advancement.  But that will require for us to overcome our `nature' and
> rely on some good old fashion Compassion and Common Sense--which,
> unfortunately, isn't common.
> 
> Does this sound like I have no faith in Humankind?
> 
> Tim

On Sun, 30 Jun 1996, Justin Cooper wrote:

> anybody feel that shaker?

Yep. Felt it. Was in the bathroom too.

> that was the first time i was pretty sure it was an earthquake right off...

Hehe. That was nothing. Let me tell you a little story. A couple of years
ago I started to go to Cal State Northridge. Me abd my roommate where
looking for a place with rooms of equal size so we wouldnt have to fight
on who gets which one. At last we found one and he left for the summer.
One day me and my ex-girlfriend decide to move everything and spend our
first night in our new apartment across the street from the school. A
couple of hours later we where finish and very tired so we decided to go
to bed at around 12:00. A couple of hours later I'am awoken by this very
loud sound and a great shakin. It was the Northridge earthquake! Yes,
folks I spend all 5 hours in my new apartment before the building was
shaken so bad that it was condemned. Also one of the partments we looked
at was in the building that had fallen and killed all those people. The
apartment was in the first floor. It was a nice place too. But the rooms
where different size. I was all 4 or 5 blocks from the epicenter. Destiny.
